The dreams of the members are to have their children become professionals, to have their own homes, to grow their businesses, to have additional businesses and their own stores.

Translated from Spanish by Kimberly Baker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Members need different amounts of loans; amounts such as 300, 450 and 600 soles for a total of 7,650 soles of loans for the Banking Community Group.

loans.name: Gina Marilu

texts.es:
La señora Gina tiene 35 años de edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal Fuente de Vida y vive en la calle Vargas Llosa 104, El Cortijo, distrito y provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta el tercer ciclo de Obstetricia, pero debido a que se casó dejó de estudiar. Tiene 3 hijos que aún dependen de ella.
Su negocio consiste en la venta de pan, rosquitas, pasteles, queso y manjar blanco.  Esta actividad lo realiza en su casa.
Con su primer crédito de S/. 300 cancelado en 4 cuotas, empezó a comprar rosquitas.
Con este crédito de S/. 1,400 soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará juguetes para vender en Navidad.
Gina sueña con tener su casa propia y un negocio muy grande.
texts.en:
Gina is 35 years old and belongs to the communal bank “Fuente de Vida” (“Fountain of Life”). She lives on Vargas Llosa Street in the province of Trujillo, La Libertad, Perú. She studied obstetrics, but did not finish because she got married. She has three children who still depend on her. Her business consists of selling bread, rosquitas (thin crusted breads in curved shapes), cakes, cheese, manjar blanco (dulce de leche). She realizes these activities in her house. With her first loan of 300.00 soles, which was canceled in four installments, she started to buy rosquitas. With this loan of 1,400.00 soles, to be repaid in six months, she will purchase toys to sell for Christmas. Gina dreams of having her own home and a large business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase toys to sell for Christmas.

loans.name: Elva

texts.es: Elva tiene 54 años, es divorciada, vive con sus hijos y sus nietos. Ella ha encontrado en la venta de queso y de panes una actividad muy rentable, ya que inició hace 5 años y le está yendo muy bien, sus productos no los vende en las ciudades cercanas, sino que los lleva como pedidos a la capital, Lima, donde pagan muy bien por ellos, y es mucho más fácil y rápido de vender que en su propia ciudad. Dentro de su actividad, lo que le agrada es viajar constantemente para la capital y así poder visitar a su hija y nieto que viven allá, sin descuidar su principal motivo de viaje, inicia desde muy temprano a repartir sus quesitos a las familias que lo solicitan y también aprovecha para aumentar sus pedidos para la próxima  quincena. Este es su primer crédito en MFP. El dinero solicitado lo invertirá en la compra y venta de mayores productos de la sierra para poder llevarlos a la capital.
texts.en:
Elva is 54 years old, divorced, and lives with her children and and grandchildren. She has discovered that selling cheese and bread is very profitable as she has been in this business for 5 years and business is good. She does not sell her products in nearby towns; rather, she sells by special order in the capital, Lima, where clients pay well, and it is much easier and quicker to sell than in her hometown. In terms of her work, what she enjoys most is travelling habitually to the capital, where she can then visit her daughter and grandchild who live there, without neglecting the main reason for her trip, as she distributes her goats' milk cheeses to families who have placed orders, as well as taking orders for her next biweekly trip. This is her first loan with MFP. She will invest the money in the purchase and sale of more products from the mountains in order to bring them to the capital.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the quantities of products for resale

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica J. is currently in the business of selling groundnuts and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Monica is 22 years old and is divorced. She has one child.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to expand her business

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development; health; education; and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Adelita

texts.es:
Doña Adelita  Gutiérrez  D. L. resiD. en el municipio  D. Soyapango,  uno D. los municipios mas poblados del departamento D. San Salvador. Ella  tiene una  pequeña tienda en al que  venD. productos perecederos como refrescos, golosinas, dulce y  otra serie D. artículos comestibles y no comestibles; a través D.  esta actividad comercial ha sacado adelante a su familia.

A sus 45 años y con un nivel académico D. secundaria,  doña Adelita busca mejorar su calidad D. vida, por lo que por segunda ocasión a solicitado a integral un micro crédito para incrementar la variedad D. artículos en su tienda, lo que le permitiría incrementar las ganancias D. su  negocio y tener un aporte económico mas sólido para ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Adelita Gutiérrez D. L. resides in the town of Soyapango, one of the most populated towns in San Salvador. She owns a small shop where she sells perishable products such as refreshments, candy, sweets and other types of edible and non-edible items. Through this commercial activity, her family has gotten ahead. At 45 years of age and with a secondary school education, Adelita is looking to improve her quality of life. As a result, for the second time, she is requesting a microloan in order to increase the variety of articles in her store which will allow her to increase her business' earnings and have a more solid economic contribution for her family and her.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock.

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg T. is a single mother. She lives with four of her children in a "ger" (a ger is a traditional nomadic Mongolian home) on a plot of land she owns herself. She used to live in the country as a herder and owned over 400 animals, while running a business making crafts at home. Her children helped her to take care of all the animals and make crafts.

In 2005, Oyunchimeg's family sold all their animals and came to live in the center of the province. After she moved, she continued her handicraft business. Oyunchimeg has lots of experience with the Mongolian, nomadic way of life. She is also skillful making handicrafts as well as Mongolian traditional clothing, stuffed toys like camels, horses and felt art. She also makes a tiny, souvenir "ger", complete with little furniture, that is sold mostly to foreign tourists. Every year she participates in many art exhibitions that are organized either in the center of Uvurhangai province or in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The loan she is taking now is to buy more cotton and silk for her craft-making.

loans.use: to buy more cotton and silk for her craft-making

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Tươi, năm nay 28 tuổi, ở Thanh Hóa. Anh chị có hai con nhỏ và đều còn đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2007. Thu nhập chính của gia đình chị hiện nay là từ hoạt động chăn nuôi, dệt chiếu của chị và việc chạy xe công nông chở vật liệu cho các công trường của chồng. Vòng vay tới chị mong muốn vay  9.000.000 đ để mua thêm lác dệt chiếu, và mua thêm lợn để chăn nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi T., 28 years old, lives in Thanh Hoa. She has two small children who are going to school. She has participated in TYM Fund since 2007. The sources of income of her family are from livestock raising and mat weaving by herself, and from materials transportation service using his own truck by her husband.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND 9,000,000 to buy supplies for mat weaving, and buy pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy supplies for mat weaving, and buy pigs to raise.

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Altantsetseg E. lives with her husband and two children in Arhanghay province, one of Mongolia’s central provinces. Both she and her husband are in the retail business at the local market. She sells household products such as small and large containers and plastic bags. Her husband sells ice cream at the local market.

Altantsetseg, with her husband, frequently travels to Narantuul market, the largest open-air market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. At Narantuul, she purchases household products and ice cream at wholesale prices and ships them to Arhanghay province.

Altantsetseg started her business in 2007 and since then the business has been doing well. Her working capital has increased from 100,000 MNT ($1 USD=1,400 MNT) to 400,000 MNT. Altantsetseg requests a loan to purchase more household products from Ulaanbaatar. At the picture: Altantsetseg and her husband Batbaatar.

loans.use: to purchase more household products for re-sale

loans.name: Mumin

texts.en:
N. Mumin is 45 years old and is married with two children. From the time he was young, Mumin has been learning to work in the small business of cattle breeding. After he married, he continued working in the same business, watching the business grow as a result of his sacrifice, and seeing his family progressing more and more.

His hope is to continue growing and improving his business to offer a better future for his children, and see them as professional, ethical, and hardworking people. For this reason, he is asking a loan of $1400 for the term of 12 months. He wants this loan to buy additional livestock. Be an important part of the growth of Mumin’s business.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase additional livestock to expand his business

loans.name: Daima Tudumu Group

texts.en:
Msimu has owned a small beauty salon and she has been a clothes and shoe seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 6 years.  She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $155. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.  

She is requesting her second loan through BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more salon items, as well as clothes and shoes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Msimu is 33 years old, married, and has five children. She also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Nuru, who has her own small business shop in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more salon items, clothes and shoes for her business.

loans.name: Isaías

texts.es: Isaías tiene 49 años, es separado, tiene 4 hijos; Amparo de 26, Jorge de 22, Lisbeth de 18 y Alberto de 14 años, quienes viven con su expareja. Desde hace 25 años se dedica a brindar el servicio de taxi, de 8 de la noche a  8 de la mañana en un auto que alquila y por el que paga parte de sus ganancias. Isaías ha reiniciado su vida y tiene una nueva pareja, la cual lo apoya mucho, es así que ahora, aparte de trabajar para las necesidades de sus hijos, también vela por su futuro al lado de su pareja. El trabajo nocturno es un riesgo, una vez lo asaltaron y fue gravemente herido, pero felizmente se ha repuesto y sigue firme trabajando para conseguir sus metas. Él dice no ser miedoso y ofrece un buen servicio a sus clientes, ya que sin importar la zona los deja en su destino. Para el futuro quiere comprar su propio carro, para no tener que seguir pagando alquiler. Este es su primer préstamo individual con MFP, ya que anteriormente fue parte de un banco comunal, siendo muy puntual con los pagos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará lubricantes para su el carro con el que trabaja, además de invertir en el restaurante de su esposa para que juntos salgan adelante.
texts.en:
Isaías is a 49-year old father of four children: 26-year-old Amparo, 22-year-old Jorge, 18-year-old Lisbeth, and 14-year-old Alberto. He is separated and his children live with his ex-wife. Isaías has driven a taxi for 25 years. He works from eight at night until eight in the morning in a rented car (a car he pays for from his earnings). Isaías has started his life anew and has a new wife who is very supportive. This is why, in addition to working to support his children, he is also starting to think about his future with his new partner. Working at night is dangerous and Isaías suffered serious injuries in an attack one time. Happily, he recovered and continues to work toward his goals. He reports that he is not a coward and will take his passengers wherever they need to go, even if it is a dangerous area. He would like to buy his own car in the future so he doesn’t have to keep paying rent. This is his first individual loan with MFP. Before this, he was a member of a communal bank and was always punctual with his payments. He will buy lubricants for the car with the loan money and also invest some in his wife’s restaurant so they can both get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de lubricantes para auto e inversión en el restaurante de su esposa

loans.name: Gnanta

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois, elle a associé à cette activité la vente de maïs. Les charbons de bois sont très utilisés pour préparer la nourriture au togo. Cette femme vend bien, elle vend même à crédit à certains de ses plus fidèles clients et récupère l’argent dans les 8 jours. Son stock étant épuisé elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 7 sacs de charbons de bois, 4 sacs de maïs et 2 sacs d’haricots.
Elle est mariée et a à sa charge 03 personnes.
texts.en:
This woman earns her living by selling charcoal; she also sells maize. Charcoal is much used to cook food in Togo. This woman sells a lot, even selling on credit to some of her most faithful customers and recuperating her money within a week. Her stock is low so she is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy 7 sacks of charcoal, 4 sacks of maize, and 2 sacks of dried beans.

She is married and responsible for 3 people.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal and cereals for resale

loans.name: Emely

texts.en:
Emely D. is from the village of Upper dumalinao, ZDS. She is 36 years old. Emely is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Emely operates a family member's business venture raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting rice for sale. Emely is just starting this business.

Emely joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emely has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Emely is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Emely from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Kuanputun A2 Group

texts.en:
Kuanputun A2 Group is a group of 8 farmers in Bone Village, Nekamese Sub District – Kupang District of East Nusa Tenggara Province. Bone Village is situated about one and a half hours' drive from Kupang City. Most of the community living in Bone Village have a background as farmers who always lean on agricultural products for supporting their family. Only a small number of the community lean on husbandry for meeting their family needs as it needs a big capital.

This group is part of a larger group of 15 cattle farmers. Due to recent devaluation of the Indonesian Rupiah, the group had to be split into 2 smaller groups to keep the loan size within the limit of $5,000 per group loan. Due to the remote location of the village, the partner was not able to re-visit the group for new pictures and an interview with a second group leader. The original photo has been split in half and the group leader mentioned is in the second sub-group currently fundraising on Kiva.

The community in Bone village usually consumes corn and cassava as their main food. They sell agricultural products such as bananas and coconuts in Inpres Market, which is situated about 37 km from Bone Village. The challenge for the community in this village is the availability of public transport to help them reach the market. The public transport only operates on Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and there is no local market available in this village so it is quite difficult for the community to sell their agricultural products.

Kuanputun A is led by a 34-year-old farmer – Simson N.. Simson was born and grew up in Bone Village. He is a married man with 3 children. They are Dian N. 6 years old - in the first grade of Elementary School, Andhika N. 3 years old, and Alfian N., 1 year old.

As a farmer, Simson spends his days cultivating the farm. He plants peanuts, cassava, vegetables, coconuts and bananas on the farm. His family always relies on the agricultural products in meeting their daily needs. Simson’s wife also helps Simson by selling their agricultural produce but they only generate a meager income so Simson has difficulty covering the children’s education fees and their daily needs.

Just the same as the other community where the people have difficulty selling their agricultural products because of lacking transportation, Simson also faces the same problem. This difficulty has driven Simson to find another way to support his family.

The Cattle Fattening program becomes a preference for Simson to support his family, as it will benefit him after fattening the cattle for a certain period. Simson and the neighbors were really excited when they heard about the TLM cattle fattening program. Simson and his neighbors then decided to form a group to receive a loan so they can buy young cattle to be fattened. They are really interested in joining this program because the price of cattle is quite expensive in the market. They are sure the profits that will be generated from this program will help them cover the family's daily needs. They hope the loan will help them to improve their living standard and provide a bright future for their children.

Note: Yesaya and Matias were replaced by their family members when the group picture was taken.

loans.use: To buy cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Ameir Mohammad Group

texts.en:
Ameir M. is the leader of the Ameir M. Group. There are two members in this group. Both of them would like to receive money for their businesses.

Ameir M. wants a loan for his taxi business. He wants to buy necessary materials for his business. Shayma Gull wants a loan for her husband’s general store. They all want to expand and improve their businesses.

With this loan, they can expand their businesses and support their families and make a better future for themselves and their families.

loans.use: Expand and improve their businesses

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou N. est âgée de 55 ans et mère de 6 enfants. Elle a une boutique où elle vend diverses marchandises. Elle souhaite renforcer son commerce et avec les revenus améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatou N. is 55 years old and the mother of six children. She has a shop where she sells various goods. She wishes to bolster her commerce and, with the revenues, to improve her family’s health, schooling, and living situation.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To operate a shop

loans.name: Morng

texts.en: Mrs. Morng L., 53, is a single mother blessed with six children. Two of them are married and live in separate homes, while the other four work at different jobs. Two are garment workers and two are silk weavers. Morng L. is married, but her husband died of senility years ago. Since 1990, Morng L. has been weaving silk, a skill she learned from her grandmother. She sells her finished product to a middleman, who then takes it to resell at the market. She has also been hired by the villagers to spin silk where she can earn extra income. Morng L. will use her loan to buy a motorcycle for her unemployed son to begin a taxi service and the rest of the loan she will use to purchase silk threads for braiding.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Kojo

texts.en:
J. is 29 years old and married; her husband is a driver. She has four children who all go to school. 

J. is currently in the business of selling beer from her home in Southern Sudan. She is requesting a loan to open a bar at a nearby market. With the extra profits resulting from her loan, she hopes to be able to build her own distillery.  

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, targeted towards war refugees returning to their native home, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bar at a nearby market

loans.name: Paort

texts.en: Mr. Paort K., a resident of Andoung Samrith village in Takeo Province, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land upon which he cultivates rice. Because he does not have enough money to buy a pump to water the field, he is requesting a loan for this purpose as well as to buy fertilizers and hire a laborer to plow the field. Mr. Paort K., single, lives with his parents.

loans.use: To buy a water pump and fertilizers and hire a laborer to plow the field

loans.name: Murod

texts.ru: Факеров Мурод проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст 51 год. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Мурод имеет высшее образование. Он болле 16 лет занимается производством муки. Мурод имеет собственную мельницу на котором производит муки, как себе так и на продажу. Кредит просит для того чтобы отремонтировать свою мельницу.
texts.en:
Murod F. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 51 years old, married and has 5 children. Murod has higher education. He has been involved in manufacturing flour for over 16 years. Murod owns a flour mill that he uses to produce flour both for himself and for sale. He is requesting a loan in order to repair his flour mill.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair of flour mill

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard D. is pastor and runs a small stand in the Bandani Market selling food products.  His business is called the Brenda Shop and he has run it for five years.  He has one employee and caters to local households and walk-in customers.

Richard's main business challenge is accessing working capital to increase his inventory.  He plans to use this KES 20,000 loan to buy more maize, flour, soap, etc. for the stand. His primary business goal is to have a bigger shop with more stock.

Richard is married with seven children.  His youngest child is a two-year-old named Barack and his oldest is a 17-year-old named Lucas.  Richard is a priest in a local church (he is pictured with his vestments on) and he describes himself as a man of the people.  His dream is to educate his children for a better future.

loans.use: To buy maize, flour, soap, salad, and bread for a small food store.

loans.name: Union De Mujeres En Desarrollo 1-4 Group

texts.en:
Mercedes, 34, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Union de Mujeres en Desarrollo (Union of Women in Development), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Mercedes and her husband have three children, ages four to fourteen, and they live in La Joya, a small town northwest of San Pedro. Mercedes has built a house of cement blocks for her family, a marked improvement over the typical wooden home. She is grateful for her loans because she knows she can pay off her home with the increased profits from her business. With this loan, her second from Esperanza International, she will be purchasing undergarments for both men and women. Mercedes will then sell them to friends, neighbors, and others in nearby towns at a small markup.

In the future, Mercedes hopes to expand her line of products to include all types of clothing for men, women, and children. She also hopes to continue improving her home to make it more comfortable for her family. Mercedes’ ultimate goal, however, is to send all of her children to college. With your support, Mercedes can continue striving towards those goals. Thank you for lending to Mercedes and the Union de Mujeres en Desarrollo group!

loans.use: To buy undergarments to sell to neighbors and friends

loans.name: C8314 Twitezimbere Group

texts.en:
Celestin is 45 years old and is married with three children aged 6, 9 and 12. He and his family live in the Northern Province of Rwanda in the region of Ruhengeri, which is approximately two hours drive from the capital city of Rwanda.

Celestin is the representative of a group called “Twitezimbere”, which consists of four people. Their common business is selling different products in their shop and different kinds of beer. This is their fifth successful year in this business, which they operate from 6 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day except Sunday.

This group is requesting the loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business. They will purchase more foodstuffs for sale such as sugar, beans and the other products, which seem to be highly demanded by their customers. After purchasing the additional foodstuffs, they will also increase the quantity of beers so that they can satisfy their customers.

With this expansion, the group hopes to attract more customers to their shop and hopefully earn more profits in the process. This, in turn, will allow them to build a secure future for their financial stability as well as for their families.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and beers to sell

loans.name: Romualde

texts.fr: A. Romualde est née vers 1947 à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Romualde vit au quartier Allomey à Allada, depuis environs 25 ans. C'est une divorcée, ayant à sa charge deux enfants. Un des enfants est scolarisé. Romualde vit seule avec ses enfants, et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Romualde n'a pas été à l'école. Il y a près de 20 ans que Romualde mène comme activité, la vente de tomates fraîches à Sékou à Allada. Romualde vend également des escargots. C'est à Bohicon, dans le département du Zou, que Romualde s'approvisionne. Romualde est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Romualde voudrait élever davantage le niveau de son activité et mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle. Cependant, Romualde manque de moyens financiers pour y parvenir. C'est la raison pour laquelle Romualde sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Romualde was born around 1947 in Allada, in Atlantique state in Bénin. Romualde has been living in the Allomey district in Allada for about 25 years. She is divorced and responsible for two children. One of them is enrolled in school. Romualde lives alone with her children and is the sole breadwinner for the family.

Romualde never went to school. She has been in her present business for about 20 years, selling fresh tomatoes in Sékou in Allada. Romualde also sells snails. She gets her merchandise from Bohicon, in Zou state. She has been a client of ALIDé for a long time, and has already received three loans from ALIDé which were correctly reimbursed.

Romualde wants to expand her business further and better respond to the needs of her clientele, however, she does not have the financial means to manage that. That is the reason why Romualde is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing 4 sacks of snails and 5 baskets of fresh tomatoes

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.es:
Nuestra socia TOAMASA, pertenecen al banco comunal “INTIWATANA”, la socia es natural D. Pisac situado en la provincia D. Calca departamento D. Cusco, está a 40 minutos D. la ciudad, es un pequeño pueblo heredero D. unas bellas construcciones incas, aquí lugar obligado D. paso para todo aquel turista que visita la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia Tomasa tiene 60 años D. edad, ella es casada con otro artesano y juntos tienen su stand en la feria D. Pisac en la plaza principal del pueblo a unos metros D. los magníficos monumentos incas, la socia también tiene 3 hijos D. 38, 35, 30 años D. edad, nuestra socia comparte este oficio por años con su esposo y amigo, la socia nos cuenta que ella tal vez fue una D. las primeras artesanas en instalarse hay y cada año lo ha hecho y esto le permitió construir su casita y criar y educar a sus tres hijos y hasta el día D. hoy es una fuente D. ingreso económico, la socia a alternado a esto la crianza D. cuyes, ella cría estos animalitos para su reproducción y venta final, nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para comprar materia prima e implementar su tienda con nuevos productos para la venta D. artesanía y parte del dinero lo destinara para comprar algunos animalitos mas.

La socia agradece y valora la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio, asi mismo se compromete en cumplir con el pago D. su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our member, Tomasa, belongs to the community bank “INTIWATANA”. She is originally from Pisac which is in the province of Calca, in the county of Cusco which is 40 minutes from the city. It is a small town which was beautifully built by the Incas, and is a place which all tourists are obliged to visit when they pass through Cusco.

Our member, Tomasa, is 60 years old and she is married to another craftsman. Together they have a stand in the Pisac market which is in the central square of the town, a few metres from the magnificent Incan monuments. Tomasa also has three kids, who are 38, 35 and 30 years old. Tomasa, her husband and her business partner have worked together for many years, and she tells us that they were perhaps the first artisans to set up there, as they have done each year. This allowed her to build her small house and raise and educate her 3 kids, and even today it is a great source of income for them. She alternates doing this with keeping guinea pigs, which she raises to breed and sell.

She would like a loan to buy raw materials and to stock her shop with new craft products. Some of the money will go towards the animals.

She is grateful and values the opportunity given to her, and she is committed to repaying the loans she owns on time.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She requires a loan to buy raw materials to make clay and to increase the number of guinea pigs to raise/La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar materia prima para elaborar arcilla y aumentar cuyes para su crianza.

loans.name: Juliette

texts.fr: Juliette N., 38 ans, mariée, mère de 5 enfants est membre du Banc Villageois depuis 5 ans. Elle a une bonne expérience en matière de crédit pour y avoir accédé à 10 fois de suite, ce qui lui permet de développer un petit commerce de citron, de poissons séché et d'huile de palme. Son objectif est d'améliorer la couverture sanitaire et scolaire de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Juliette N. is a 38 year-old married mother of five; she has been a member of the Banc Villageois for five years. She has significant experience with loans, having received 10 consecutive ones that have enabled her to develop a small lemon, dried fish and palm oil business. Her aim is to improve her children’s health and education.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen her business activities

loans.name: Chona

texts.en: Ms. Chona L., a thirty-year-old single mother from Remedios, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental is our featured entrepreneur. She has one son. To make a living, she presently operates a sari-sari (variety) store. She has been in the business for six years and earns an average net income of not less than PHP 3,000. Upon hearing the about Paglaum MPC, she joined the cooperative in the 2009. As an active member, she can request a loan of up to PHP 5,000 for capital to invest in her sari-sari store and in her other line of business, in which she buys and sells dried fish and longganisa (sausage). The future income from this loan will be used for loan repayments, sustaining her family's basic needs, and saving for her child's future.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store and for her business buying and selling dried fish and longganisa

loans.name: Hok

texts.en:
To make a living, Mr. Hok N. owns a small enterprise selling furniture around the province. From this, he is able to generate at least $5 of income each day to be used to cover his family's expenses. He has a life partner in his wife, who is a local tailor. She sews sets of clothes ordered by people for a fee. In addition, she buys clothing in bulk to resell at profit. 

Hok N. was born in 1977. He has established a small family home where he lives with other members. Hok N. sees that his wife’s enterprise is a profitable one, and he is applying for a loan for his wife to improve her clothing sales business.

loans.use: To improve a clothing sales business

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es:
La Sra. Lidia Es una cliente nueva ha trabajado antes en el banco de emprendimiento, Primavera de Mercurio, ha mostrando responsabilidad, ella tiene la determinación de llegar a constituir un taller mas grande, es emprendedora, su taller y domicilio es de carácter familiar. Junto a su pareja Osvaldo quien es chofer asalariado interprovincial,  la Sra. Realiza sus ventas en el barrio minero. La venta de sus mantas la realiza a vendedores en las ferias de la ciudad de el alto,  quedándose hasta parte de la mañana para poder distribuir sus mantas y por la tarde se dedica a la producción de sus mantas. La Sra. Produce las mantas a crochet mantas tejidas a mano con lana de alpaca ( La alpaca es un animal de fina estampa, armoniosa en su caminar, de cuerpo esbelto cubierto de fibra que en su conjunto se denomina vellón. Presenta almohadillas plantares, característica que le otorga la condición de animal ecológico al no dañar el pasto, ni provocar erosión.  La lana de alpaca es una fibra tan cálida y única que por cientos de años muchos países han tratado de conseguirla. Sin embargo, ellos no podrían tener rebaños de alpacas en el extranjero. Las alpacas nunca se reproducen a menos que vivan en tierras vírgenes. Perú y Bolivia han firmado tratados internacionales para asegurar su monopolio sobre la alpaca ya que es nuestro legado nacional), realiza sus productos por mayor o menor según los pedidos que tenga, con el dinero del credito comprara lana de alpaca al por mayor y asi poder realizar sus mantas, su mayor anhelo de lidia es ampliar su negocio y tener sus propia casa.
Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgación del crédito.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lidia is a new customer who previously worked with “Primavera de Mercurio” (Spring of Mercury) Community Bank. She has shown herself to be very responsible. She is determined to build a larger workshop. She is very enterprising. Her workshop and home have a familiar character. Along with her husband Osvaldo, who is an interprovincial salaried driver, she sells her product in the mining areas. She sells her blankets to salespeople at the markets in the highlands. She sells her blankets in the morning and constructs them in the afternoon. She makes handmade, crochet blankets out of alpaca wool. (The alpaca is delicate footed herd animal with a slim body covered with fiber that she gathers for fleece. They have padded feet that allow them to tread lightly on the grass. The animals don’t damage the ecology of the region or cause erosion. Alpaca wool is high quality. For many hundreds of years other countries have tried to acquire alpacas. Foreign countries have not been able to maintain alpaca herds. Alpacas don’t reproduce unless they live on open land. Perú and Bolivia have signed international treaties in order to assure their monopoly over the alpaca, as they are their national legacy.) She sells her blankets to the wholesale and retail markets, depending on the requests that she has. With this loan she will buy wholesale alpaca wool and use it to make her blankets. Her major goal is to grow her business and have her own house. She is very thankful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence they have given her by granting her this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy alpaca wool to use for crocheting her blankets.

loans.name: Lucien

texts.fr: G. Lucien est né en 1949 à Abomey, dans le département du Zou au Bénin. Marié à AFEDJOU Odette, Lucien est père de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Lucien vit depuis une vingtaine d'année à fidjrossè, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Depuis huit ans, Lucien exerce comme activité, la vente de sacs de maïs à son domicile. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Lucien contribue efficacement aux charges familiales. Lucien s'approvisionne à Kandi, dans le Nord du Bénin. Lucien a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit à ALIDé, et l'a bien remboursé. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Lucien sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
G. Lucien was born in 1949 in Abomey, in Zou County, Benin.  Married to AFEDJOU Odette, he is the father of five children, who have all attended school.  He has been living for about twenty years in Fidjrossè, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  For eight years, he has been operating a business selling sacks of corn at his house.  He gets his supplies in Kandi, in northern Benin.  Thanks to the revenues from his business, he is effectively helping to cover family expenses.  Lucien has already benefited from one ALIDé loan and has repaid it.  Facing the growing number of customers of his, he is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun S., age 45, is a tailor and earns an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband (pictured) is a construction foreman, earning an income of USD 10 per day. They work together to cover the family expenses. They live with their four children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for its high-quality rice products. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more construction materials to expand her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s studies.  

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase more construction materials to expand the business

loans.name: Leliosa

texts.en:
Leliosa B., 33, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Daniel B., a businessman, she is blessed with one child in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own fruit stand while operating a hardware store selling mainly carpentry tools. She also raises a few hogs for additional income.

Leliosa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 23,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business, buying more products to be sold at her hardware store to replenish her current product stock.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more fruits to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Toir

texts.en:
Toir is a 54 year old, married father of 5 children. Toir owns a grocery store and provides for his family with the revenue generated by the grocery store. He is requesting a loan of $2700 US Dollars to increase his stock. Toir is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once and awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is that his children will progress by means of their studies.  He believes his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.     

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs to increase the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Jose Bldelomar

texts.es: El señor José tiene 52 años de edad, es casado y tiene tres hijos todos mayores de edad y viven aparte. Su esposa trabaja como comerciante en el mercado, que es donde trasladan las cosechas que venden. El señor José se dedica a la compra-venta de cosechas, estas se las compra a las mismas personas del mercado, en su mayoría son cosechas de aguacate y cítricos, aunque a veces compra banano. El ya tiene 35 años de  dedicarse a esta actividad, la cual dio inicio primeramente con su papa que era poseedor de una pequeña finca. Por lo que él viajaba a Managua y a Masaya a vender las frutas al mercado. El señor desea invertir en la compra de cosecha de aguacate, ya que es el tiempo de de esta fruta. Su sueño es comprar un vehículo para trasladar el producto ya que actualmente tiene que transportar las cosechas a través de los buses.
texts.en:
Sr. José is 52 years old, married, and has two adult children who live apart from him. His wife works as a merchant at the farmer’s market. Sr. José buys and sells produce from the same people at the market. Avocados and citrus fruits are what he mostly trades, but sometimes he buys bananas. He has been in this business for 35 years and started when his father owned a small farm.

Sr. José travels to Managua and Masaya to sell his fruits at the market. He wants to invest in avocados since this is the season for this fruit. His dream is to purchase a vehicle for hauling his products since he currently has to travel with them on buses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase avocados to sell

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.es:
Consuelo tiene 56 años D. edad, es casada y vive junto a su esposo y a sus tres hijos en el distrito agrícola D. Nueva Arica, una zona D. terreno bastante accidentado, dada su cercanía a la sierra norte del país. Se encuentra ubicada a una hora y media D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo.

Se dedica a trabajar criando y vendiendo animales desD. hace mas D. diez años, ella cría animales menores en su vivienda y cuando estos ya han alcanzado su máximo nivel D. desarrollo los ofrece en venta los días martes en una feria que se instala en la ciudad D. Cayaltí. 

Consuelo desea adquirir alimento balanceado para mejorar la elimentación D. sus animales D. modo que pueda venderlos a un mejor precio, para lograr su objetivo ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 1000 nuevos soles.

Consuelo es una mujer traajadora y responsable, en la zona sus vecinos y conocidos le consideran una persona D. trato amable y que ayuda a los que la necesitan
texts.en:
Consuelo is 56 years old, married and lives alongsiD. her husband and three children in the agricultural district of Nueva Arica, a quite hilly area of land, thanks to its proximity to the northern mountains of the country. She is located one and a half hours from the city of Chiclayo. She has been dedicated to the work of raising and selling animals for more than ten years. She raises young animals in her house and when they have reached their maximum level of development, she sells them on Tuesdays in a market in the city of Cayalti. Conseulo wishes to acquire balanced feed to improve her animals' nutrition so she can sell them at a better price. To achieve her objective she has requested for the first time a loan of 1000 new soles from Edpyme Alternativa. Consuelo is a hard-working and responsible woman. In her area, her neighbors and acquaintances consider her to be an amiable person who helps those in need.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase feed to improve the growth of her animals that she sells.

loans.name: Mrs. Sokheng Toch Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Slab Ta Aon village, in Kandal province, sixteen people make up a village bank loan. Mrs. Sokheng T., born in 1973, is a village bank president. She has been selected by the other members, who will each use a portion of their loan for various purposes. Mrs. Sokheng T. owns a general store in the local village where she earns some money to support her family. Since this business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve her business, Mrs. Sokheng T. is asking for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. Her husband, Mr. Sokhom Kham, is a construction worker. Through this activity, they support four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are attending school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell.

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en: Alfredo O. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 51 years old. Alfredo is married and has five children. To make a living, Alfredo raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Alfredo has been engaged in his business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Alfredo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alfredo has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Alfredo is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. This will be the second loan taken out by Alfredo from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also offers savings, insurance and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster-group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria W. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize, millet, sorghum, and pealed dried cassava. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize and sorghum to sell. Victoria is 46 years old and is married; her husband is a small-scale farmer. She has three children who do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school.

loans.use: To stock more bags of maize and sorghum

loans.name: Cristina's Group

texts.en: Cristina A. is from the village of Magdalena, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 31 years old. Cristina is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Cristina is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Cristina runs a general store, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Cristina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Cristina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Cristina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Cristina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Roger Ivan

texts.es:
el sr. Roger Ivan R. Quiñonez tiene 33 años de edad, vive en la Colonia Nueva Esperanza en la ciudad de Danli, Roger se dedica al comercio su actividad principal es la venta de articulos para el hogar, negocio que opera bajo el nombre de "Jehová jireh" y que cuenta con 3 años de experiencia en la administración del mismo.
durante este tiempo lo ha sabido administrar ya que su negocio a crecido y sus condiciones de vida ha mejorado.

Roger vende artículos para el hogar en diferentes partes del departamento de El Paraiso, para lo que utiliza un vehiculo tipo camión el que es de su propiedad y además cuenta con dos empleados.
tiene una gran clientela la que en su mayoría son personas que adquieren los artículos al crédito.

El Sr. Roger es casado su esposa es ama de casa y producto del matrimonio tienen tres hijos, actualmente estan cursando los estudios primarios.

el credito lo utilizara para la compra de mas articulos para el hogar ya que la demanda es grande y no tiene suficiente capital para invertir en su negocio.
texts.en:
Roger Ivan R. Quiñonez is 33 years old and lives in the Nueva Esperanza "New Hope" residential area in the city of Danli. Roger is a businessman whose primary activity is the sale of items for the home. His business, which he has run for the last three years, is named "Jehová Jireh," or "God Our Provider." During this time he has learned how to be a manager, as evidenced by the growth of his business and improvement in his living conditions. Roger sells items for the home in different parts of the El Paraiso "Paradise" Department. He uses his own truck to do this and also has two employees. He has a large clientele, the majority of whom buy merchandise on credit. Roger is married. His wife takes care of the home and their three children, who are in primary school. The loan proceeds will be used to buy more items for the home, given that demand is high and Roger does not have sufficient capital to invest in his business.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of dividers, shelves, and furniture for the bathroom and kitchen.

loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
Mrs. Phally S. (in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Sorn Soy, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh  They married in 1993 and have three sons, all of them in school.

Phally has been selling grocery items for more than 4 years. She buys grocery items from the market for resale at her store in the village. Her husband has been a mason for more than 15 years.

She is requesting a loan of $1,200 to continue expanding her business by purchasing grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To continue expanding her business by purchasing grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Tebib

texts.ru:
Tebib Y. 35 let. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey sin kotoromu 7 let on uchitsya v shkole i doch kotoroy 2 qoda. Tabib jivet v Fizuli region, pasolok Bala Behmenli  vmeste so svoyey semyoy. 

Tabib uje 6 let rabotayet v etom biznesse prodaji produktov. Etomu biznessu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo otca. Eto uje vtoroy ssud Tabiba, v pervuyu ssudu on bral 1000 $, a seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkt dlya svoyeqo maqazina , on xochet nachat prodavat v svayom maqazine takje moyushiye sredstva.

http://partners.kiva.org/lend/4798
texts.en:
Tebib Y. is 35 years old.  He is married and has 2 children: a 7-year-old son, who attends school and a 2-year-old daughter.  Tebib lives in the Fuzuli region, in the Bala Behmenli village together with his family.

Tebib has been working in the food products sale business for 6 years.  He learned this business from his father.  This is Tebib's second loan.  His first loan was for $1000, and now he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy food products for his store.  He wants to start selling cleaning supplies at his store.

loans.use: Purchase of products for resale

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine R. is from Malabor, Tibiao Antique, Philippines. She is 21 years old, married to Rico R. and they are blessed with one child, Gerica.

The couple did not finish their studies because they lacked financial and moral support from their parents. Instead they are already used to working at a very young age and their education has been set aside. Since they are elementary graduates, job opportunities are very few for them; they find difficulty in seeking a job. 

Geraldine now realizes the importance of education and that is why they are really striving in order to earn an income and savings for the future of their children.

In 2009, she joined ASHI because she believes that this institution could help them realize their dreams. She maintains her good performance in ASHI because she wants to access more capital so that she will also have a bigger income.

She is requesting Php 9,000 for her second loan. This amount will be utilized as additional capital for her business buying and selling fruit and dried fish. The income that they will get from this business is a great help to the family to cover their basic needs.

Finally, Geraldine is very thankful to ASHI and to those people who give her opportunities despite her educational problems and living conditions. According to her, she will do her best in order to improve her business so that the funders and the institution will not regret putting their trust in her.

loans.use: Fruit, Vegetable and Dried Fish Vending

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita C. is from the village of Sinamar, Roxas, Isabela. She is 54 years old. Rosita is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Rosita owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn to sell. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2007, Rosita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Rosita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther K. is a lady aged 24 years, married and a mother to only one child who is three years old. Her spouse is called Peter Maina and he works in the motorcycle taxi business.  

Esther runs a retail shop and this has been her business for two years.  She is committed to making the business successful. 

This is the third loan taken out from KADET after repaying the previous loan very well. She will use the borrowed amount to buy: 10 bags of flour, 25 bags of sugar, 10 cartons of cooking fat, and other shop supplies.

She has a desire to add one more motorcycle to her husband's business as he also contributes to the family income. She is therefore working toward this goal and she hopes to be a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy stock for a general shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua O. is 30 years old and married with two children, both aged 3 years old, whom they hope to educate to the university level. His business is located among many other businesses beside a highway in the Kisumu region of Kenya, known as the lake region since it harbors the famous Lake Victoria. Joshua's business is well known as Kandong'a and Sons Enterprises. He makes and sells such items as saucepans, trays and cookers to the local people. He has been operating this business for 8 years and has three employees. He says that this business is profitable and his major challenge is financial constraints. He is using this loan of KES 40,000 to buy scrap metal to make more items to sell as Christmas festivities approach. He hopes to be a big manufacturer of metal products. He describes himself as goal oriented, determined and ambitious.

loans.use: to buy scrap metal

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina is from the village of Lagag, Sindangan, Zamboanga Del Norte. She is 39 years old and a group member with PMPC. Avelina is married and has three children, two of whom are students while the eldest is in Manila. To make a living, Avelina operates a business of selling vegetable snacks in the local community. Avelina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $88 a month for these activities. 

In 2008, Avelina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor O. O. is a 32-year-old married man. His wife is a student at a local college and they do not have any children yet. Victor sells mangoes, oranges and other fruits. His business is located at Kakamega, a region in Kenya commonly referred to as the sugarbelt and known for the production of sugarcane.

He has been in this business for the last two years. This business is profitable for him but his major challenge is the fact that fruits are seasonal and thus, there are some seasons within the year when there is not much business due to unavailability of fruits. However, he works very hard from early to late evening to keep his business doing well.

He is requesting a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy mangoes to grow his business and meet customer demand. He hopes to grow his business and stock vegetables, which he will be selling wholesale. He also hopes to purchase a plot of land and put up rental houses. 

Victor describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: Mangoes

loans.name: Mario Antonio

texts.es:
Mario es un joven de 25 años de edad, vive en San Rafael oriente departamento de San Miguel, junto a su esposa y dos hijos de 6 y 4 años de edad, se dedica a vender ropa y medicinas, no tiene horario de ventas y por el momento solicita un préstamo para comprar mercadería, ropa y medicamentos de diferentes clases, con la inversión espera atraer a nuevos clientes y elevar sus ventas.
Sueña con un gran negocio, con muchos clientes y con un mejor vida al lado de su familia, pero sobretodo que sus hijos tengan una carrera universitaria.
texts.en: Mario is a 25 year old young man,  He lives in the department of San Miguel Oriente with his wife and two children, ages 6 and 4.  He sells clothing and medicines but doesn’t have sales hours at the moment.  He is requesting the loan to buy merchandise, clothing, and various types of medicine. With the investment, he hopes to attract new customers and increase his sales.  He dreams of having a large business with many customers and a better life with his family.  Above all, however, he wants his children to attend college.

loans.use: To buy clothing and medicine

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Zoila Fabiana

texts.en:
Zoila is 33 years old, married, and has one child. She lives in the highland region on Totonicapan, Guatemala. Zoila works as a tutor in her community and she is known as a responsible, hardworking person. Her husband, who also works as a tutor, also helps support the family. 

Zoila is requesting a loan to cover some personal family expenses. She hopes that this loan will help her improve her family's quality of life. This is Zoila's first loan through Asociacion ASDIR.

loans.use: to cover personal family expenses

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es:
Edgar Eduardo C. T. tiene 29 años de edad y fabrica artesanías propias de su naturaleza cultural el teje hamacas y bolsos en los diferentes modelos que quiere el cliente que ve en las revistas y que el mismo apropia para enriquecer su mercadeo. Edgar, como artesano de tradición familiar se inicia en el negocio desde el año 2004 cuando realizó sus estudios como administrador  de empresas agropecuarias, pero no encontró empleo y decidió acudir a su potencial y a su aptitud para el emprendimiento y las artesanías.
Él ha recibido  dos créditos de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, incluyendo  su credikiva   con el comprará materias primas para hacer hamacas y bolsos, inversión que pronostica ser  exitosa porque esta basada en pedidos de su clientes, esta es importante para Edgar porque cuando no tiene productos fabricados en su taller, por su muy bajo capital, el  debe responder  a  las solicitudes de sus compradores comprando   a un mayor precio y se   disminuyen sus utilidades. 
Desde que recibió su primer crédito con la Fundación el ha logrado aumentar sus ganancias y con ellas compró una maquina para elaborar bolsos; antes de recibir este apoyo para lograr capitalizarse   acudía a sus familiares y estos le ayudaban prestándole el dinero, ahora es un poco mas autónomo respecto a los que en ese momento le tendieron su mano.
Edgar vive en San Jacinto, municipio del departamento de Bolívar, con su esposa que también es artesana y es su mayor apoyo, con ella construye su sueño de tener un gran almacén en la carretera troncal del occidente, donde se encuentra  ubicado el sector artesanal de este municipio.
texts.en:
Edgar Eduardo C. T. is 29 years old and makes his own traditional handicrafts.  He weaves hammocks and bags in different styles based on what customers see in magazines which he also uses for marketing purposes.  Based on family tradition, Edgar began his business in 2004 when he studied agricultural business administration.  He was unable to find a job and decided to use his entrepreneurial and artistic skills and aptitude.

He has received two loans through the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, including his crediKiva, which he will use to purchase materials to make hammocks and bags.  The investment is bound to be successful because already has taken orders from customers.  Because of his lack of capital, Edgar usually does not keep an inventory of products so he must supply orders by paying a higher price for materials which means less profit.

Since receiving his first loan through the Foundation he has been able to increase his earnings and buy a machine to make the bags.  Before he was able to do this he had to go to family members for capital.  Now he is more independent.

Edgar lives in San Jacinto, in the department of Bolivar.  His wife is also an artisan and she is his greatest support.  Together they are building their dream of having a large shop along the main road west of town where the crafts sector is located.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make hammocks and bags

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is 39 years old. She is married and has three children. Her oldest child is 13 years old. Vilma has been engaged in farming for five years. She grows rice to sell in her community. Vilma also started a sari-sari store to add income for her family.

Vilma requested this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. She hopes to have a better harvest. Vilma also wishes for her children to finish college and to have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn A. works hard to support her four children. She is married and has a livestock business in the Philippines.

Analyn requested a PHP 1,800 loan through NWTF to buy an Envirofit cookstove.

She is getting the Envirofit cookstove because she wants to save money by using the dried wood she can pick from her surroundings.

Analyn is aware that by using the Envirofit cookstove, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase a Envirofit cookstove

loans.name: Rina

texts.en:
This is 23 year-old Rina M.. She is married and has one child, aged 4. In 2000, she established her business making brass religious statues. Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buys raw materials for her business. In the future, Rina plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

Nepal has a long and rich history of traditional handicrafts. Throughout the Kathmandu Valley, skilled artisans produce unique pieces of art that reflect Nepal's cultural diversity. Terra cotta pottery comes from the red clay of the surrounding Himalayan foothills. Bronze and silver statuettes are formed using wax molds and intricate hand tool finishing. In Patan, Newari culture and traditions are reflected in the images and symbols etched into metal or formed in stone. With the help of a Kiva loan, Nepal's artisans are able to purchase raw materials in greater volume. This increase in volume allows a single artisan to work on several pieces at the same time while increasing her profit margin.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her statue making business

loans.name: Carlos Ernesto

texts.es:
Carlos, reside en la ciudad de San Miguel, es taxista, vive con su esposa y dos hijos de 11 y 14 años de edad, él trabaja desde hace 16 años, fue iniciativa propia, trabaja todos los días de 6:00am a 7:00pm.
Él solicita un préstamo para la compra de repuestos para el taxi, ya que este ha presentado problemas mecánicos, este préstamo le ayudara a mantenerlo en buenas condiciones, así prestar un buen servicio evitando un accidente.
Su aspiración es apoyar a sus hijos, por medio del trabajo, brindarles seguridad y la culminación de sus estudios.
texts.en:
Carlos lives in the city of San Miguel. He’s a Taxi Driver.  He lives with his wife and two children who are 11 and 4 years of age.   He’s been working for the last 16 years.  He started on his own initiative.  He works every day from 6am until 7pm.

He is asking for a loan to buy spare parts for the taxi because it’s having some mechanical problems.  This loan will help him maintain it in good condition to provide good service and avoid accidents.

His goal is to support his children through his work, to provide them with security and the completion of their schooling.

loans.use: to buy replacement parts for the taxi.

loans.name: Ana Rosa

texts.es:
la joven Ana Rosa tiene 30 años de edad, vive en la colonia Carranza de la ciudad de Choluteca y se dedica a la venta de lacteos desde hace mas de 4 años, su negocio esta ubicado en la terminal municipal de buses de Choluteca. Ana tiene muchos clientes ya que por este lugar transitan muchas personas.
Ana es madre soltera y vive con sus hijos en la casa de sus padres.
sus tiempos libres lo dedica a visistar a su familia. 
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de queso, quesillo, cuajada y mantequilla, ahora las ventas son mayores y muchas veces se queda sin producto.
texts.en:
Ana Rosa, 30, lives in the city of Choluteca’s Carranza neighborhood.  She has sold dairy products for over 4 years.  Her business is located in the Choluteca Municipal Bus Terminal.  Ana has many customers because there are many passersby in this place.  She is a single mother living with her children in her parents’ house.  She uses her free time to visit her family.

She will use the loan to buy cheese, cottage cheese, soft cheese and butter now that sales have increased and often she’s left without any product.

loans.use: to buy cheese, cottage cheese, soft cheese and butter.

loans.name: Denise

texts.fr: Née le 08 Octobre 1980 au Bénin, Denise est mariée à un certain Brice. Le couple à deux  enfants, tous à charges et scolarisés. Denise n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Denise mène comme activité depuis près de huit ans la vente de produits congelés et des produits divers (savons, pâtes alimentaires, conserves, détergents, etc.). Parallèlement à cette activité, Denise vend des cartes de recharge GSM, des boissons fraîches, des vivres. Grâce au revenu que lui génère ses activités, Denise contribue aux différentes dépenses de sa famille. Denise s’approvisionne dans le plus grand marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour améliorer son niveau de vie et son revenu, Denise sollicite pour une première fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: Born on October 8, 1980 in Benin, Denise is married to a man by the name of Brice. They have two dependent children, both in school. Denise attended only primary school. In order to provide for herself and her children, since almost eight years ago Denise  has been selling frozen foods and miscellaneous items (soaps, pasta, canned food, detergents etc). Parallel to this, Denise sells recharge cards for cellular phones, cold beverages and staple foods. Thanks to her income, Denise is able to cover different family expenses. She stocks up at the largest markest in Benin. With the goal of meeting her clients’ needs and improving her income and her life conditions, Denise is seeking her first loan from ALIDé.

loans.use: to buy miscellaneous items ( canned food, detergents, soap, pasta etc) and frozen foods

loans.name: Samar

texts.en:
Samar is 42 years old and a hard-working woman; she has three sons and one daughter.

Samar started almost five years ago with a small humble shop, a dry cleaning business in Al Zarqa, where she has special machines and equipment for cleaning clothes and ironing them. And since then she has expanded her services to include dyeing clothes and fabric in the same shop.

Living through these successful five years has given her the courage to expand the work area and try to recruit employees to help her serve her customers as fast as she can. That’s why she applied for this loan.

loans.use: To expand the work area and try to recruit employees.

loans.name: Alina

texts.en: Alina keeps beehives and livestock and cultivates land. Additionally, Alina works at the post-office as a postman, but her salary is too low to cover the family’s daily costs. Alina would like to increase her livestock and start cultivating potatoes. With the requested loan, she plans to purchase a special sort of potato seeds and livestock. With the loan’s help, Alina will increase her business and get more income. Additional income will help her renovate the house and improve her family’s living conditions. Alina lives together with her husband and daughter.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds and livestock

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 48 years old and lives in Lopoc, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married with three children.

Elsie has a general store business and earns approximately 6,000 PHP each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for 14,900 PHP to purchase more stock for her general store.

Elsie has been a member of PMPC for one year. In the future, Elsie hopes to expand her store.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store business.

loans.name: Marve Luz

texts.es: Marve Luz es una mujer muy emprendedora que vive en el municipio de Baranoa con su esposo y sus dos hijas menores de edad, allí se  dedica a la  venta de Prendas de productos de murano y de plata, así como a la lencería; su principal M. lo constituyen los docentes  del municipio a quienes ofrece –financiamientos con pagos mensuales.
