While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing & selling bamboo items and also weaving mats for 'nipa' (palm frond) huts. She also sells them to local community members. Eudesa is just starting this business.

In 2008, Eudesa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eudesa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Eudesa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the second loan taken out by Eudesa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Zinunula Community Bank Group, Nansana

texts.en:
The lucrative nature of her oil-selling business in Nansana, Kampala, has got her thinking big. She is looking at a prospective scenario in the future where she will be running her own petrol (gasoline) stations in Kampala.

This is the ambitious story of K. Deborah, a 35-year-old married mother of eight. She has been selling fuel for the last six years and has managed to educate most of her children to university level as a result of this. With her monthly earnings above 50,000 and rising every year, her optimism is justified.

It’s in Deborah’s future plans to expand her business. She envisages a situation where she will be able to run her own fuel pump stations. She plans to embark on this project as soon she gets this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more jerrycans of fuel to sell

loans.name: Kyarutanga Twetungura, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Putting up his hand at the extreme left is A. John Baptist. He is a hardworking and an ever-optimistic 35-year-old married father of five children aged between 15 and 8 years.

John Baptist operates a growing produce and retail business in Bwera, Ibanda, dealing in general merchandise such as soap, matches, soft drinks, beer, salt, sugar and cereals. With a business longevity of twelve years, he has managed to significantly sustain and improve his family’s welfare.

To all appearances, John Baptist’s future business prospects look rosy with close to 240,000 Ugandan shillings coming in monthly from his business. He envisions an even greater profit as he gets this loan, anticipating being in a position to buy more merchandise for his business. This will enable him to expand his business and also enable him to earn more revenue.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his business

loans.name: Nally

texts.en:
For a simple woman like Nally M., happiness doesn’t have to be very expensive. Her life may be poor yet, being blessed with a very loving and supportive husband and children, any trials and problems she encounters in her everyday life seemed to be easy to overcome. She inspires her family to be content with what they have at the present and to work hard for anything else they feel is important to have. Nally believes that everything she dreams of for herself and family will eventually come true. 


With that approach, through her, her family enjoys the opportunity ASHI has given them. Loans she has been receiving have enabled them to start their own income generating activities. They were able to purchase a motorcycle and a second-hand sidecar for a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) which is for her husband’s transportation business. Nally also has her own salt buying and selling business. Large volumes of salt are sold in the market and during the town’s market day when may people and small entrepreneurs come from other municipalities to buy different commodities for personal consumption and business. Nally sells her salt wholesale.

Proceeds of Nally's and her husband’s businesses are the sole source of income for their family. As parents, they are also supporting the needs of their two children who are 19 and 24. Once Nally has the capability to open a saving fund, she will be motivating her children to go back to college as they are just high school graduates. Nally is hopeful that their businesses will become stable and profitable with the support of loans she can access. Presently, Nally’s two daughters are helping her in the business.

loans.use: To purchase a new sidecar and make a down payment on a new motorcycle used as transportation in her salt business

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny P. is from the village of  Valencia Bukidnon. She is 39 years old. Jenny is separated from her spouse and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jenny owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Jenny has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jenny joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jenny is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Jenny from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Bakyt

texts.en:
Bakyt B. was born in the town of Kara-Balta in the north of the Kyrgyz Republic, where he still lives. He is 29 years old, married and has two children; his son is 6 and his daughter is 3 years old. Bakyt and his family live in his mother’s house. 

He started to work when he was 20. In the beginning, he worked at a private car wash, and later he was hired by a car-repair shop as a mechanical assistаnt.  When he had earned the necessary start-up capital, he bought his first car – a used Ford Sierra. From this moment, he changed his job and became a private taxi driver.

In 2008, Bakyt had a car accident, which was the fault of another driver. Bakyt got injured, and his car became unsuitable for his taxi business, so Bakyt sold it. Bakyt and his family met difficult times as he was the only breadwinner for his family and kids. 

After full recovery, he decided to go back into business and took a loan from the Bai Tushum Company to purchase a car. He bought a Volkswagen Golf produced in 1986. The loan was used for its initial purpose and repaid on time and without any delay. This car is the only means of income in the B. family, but its technical condition does not allow it to carry out safe passenger transportation. The car needs to be repaired.

That’s why Bakyt applied for another loan, to repair his car so that he can continue to work as a taxi driver. Part of the new loan Bakyt wants to use to renovate the house where his family lives.

In the future, Bakyt wants to buy a good minivan with seven seats and continue to work as a taxi driver. Bakyt’s family now lives in a small, old house. Bakyt dreams of buying a good, large house for his family, where they could have their own household.

loans.use: To repair a taxi

loans.name: Chorn's Group

texts.en: This group loan is being requested by five people who live in Pongro village, Takeo province. They will each use a portion of their loan to support their varied businesses. Mrs. Chorn S. is a group leader who is 35 years old, and was selected by the other members. She is a farmer and owns a 2.5 hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell. She is also a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Ret Neak, owns a mill in the local village. Now she has some problems because her soil in her fields is infertile. So to improve production of rice, Mrs. Chorn S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, and she will use the rest of the loan to buy piglets for breeding. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are seamstresses in garment factory and one of whom is in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and invest in pig breeding business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing of foodstuffs, sim-cards and prepaid mobile phone cards

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita A. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 60 years old. Carmelita is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Carmelita owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from gathering and selling seaweed to the market. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years.

Carmelita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Felicita

texts.es:
Felicita, D. 52 años, está casada con Raúl D. 60 años, ambos tienen 6 hijos pero vive solo con dos D. ellos en su casa propia, ubicada en el pueblo D. Pian. Todos los días desD. muy temprano sale a vender menestras en el mercado central D. su comunidad; con el dinero que obtiene compra los alimentos del día, pero la actividad que más le gusta a Felicita es la agricultura, ya que hace 25 años se dedica a ello, sembrando, zanahoria y espinaca, productos D. los cuales después venD. en la capital del país. 
Estar en el campo es lo que le agrada D. su trabajo, “es tranquilo”, afirma, es por ello que quiere más adelante comprar su propio terreno para sembrar mayor cantidad D. verduras y poder tener mayor capital. Es el séptimo crédito con MFP y le encanta pertenecer a su banco comunal, porque aprenD. mucho en las charlas educativas que le brindan constantemente. Con los dos mil nuevos soles que solicita, comprará semillas, abonos y fertilizantes para  poder sembrar.
texts.en:
Felicita, age 52, is married to 60 year old Raúl. They have six children, but they only live with two of them. They live in their own house in the town of Pian. She leaves very early everyday to sell vegetables in the central market in her community. With the money that she gets she buys food for the day. However, the activity that Felicita likes best is farming. She has been farming for 25 years. She plants carrots and spinach, products that she later sells in the capital of the country. It pleases her to work in the fields. She says that it is peaceful. That is why she wants to later buy her own land to plant a greater quantity of vegetables and be able to have more capital. This is her seventh loan with MFP. She is delighted to belong to her communal bank because she learns a lot in the educational talks that are always offered. She will use the 2,000 soles she is requesting to buy seeds and natural and chemical fertilizers to be able to plant.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Nurullo

texts.en:
Nurullo is married with three children. He owns a small store that sells car parts. His business is located close to a car maintenance shop. This gives him an opportunity to have many repeat clients and a stable business. Nurullo has been in this business for 12 years. During this time, he has developed a good business network that supplies him with the parts his clients order. Nurullo would like to borrow 7500 Somoni to purchase spare parts in bulk. He has gained a reputation for responsibility with his financial obligations and for keeping his word. We are happy to have another opportunity to assist him with the operation of his business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and having witnessed the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC, and communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language. Today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to offer poor and low-income clients a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase a broader range of car parts

loans.name: Fanny

texts.en:
Fanny M. is from the village of Poblacion, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Fanny is separated from her spouse and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Fanny owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. Fanny has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2010, Fanny joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Fanny is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase food & beverages for the restaurant. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Fanny from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food & beverages for the restaurant.

loans.name: Katanda I Tukwatanise Group-Bushenyi

texts.en: G. Danson of Katanda I Tukwatanise group-Bushenyi is 32 years old and operates a general merchandise shop from his home area of Kanyashande, Bushenyi. He has operated the shop and also made agricultural produce sales to the local population for over 3 years. Alongside the retail shop he grows bananas, beans and more all that help him earn revenue. Danson makes 120,000 UGX per month; a figure he says will not substantially sustain his business for the near future. Therefore he is seeking a loan to help him purchase more goods to restock his shop and thus be able to make more sales.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for a general store

loans.name: Rodgers

texts.en:
Rodgers S. is a forty-four year old dairy farmer in Kiwandani Kilifi.  He is married to Susan Karisa and together they are blessed with three children.

He is applying for a second loan KES 27,000 from KADET and he intends to purchase another dairy cow for his farm and will use the anticipated profit to educate his children.  He hopes to greatly increase his cash flow.

loans.use: To purchase another dairy cow.

loans.name: Embajadores 5 Group

texts.en:
Adamilka is the coordinator of her group Embajadores 5 (ambassadors 5). She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and 3 children. She says that her most difficult challenge is to give credit to her clients. In the meantime, she plans to continue enjoying sharing with her family and friends.

Adamilka is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has had her business for 6 months, starting with her first loan. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying toys and women´s accessories. She will use the profits invest in her business and to give her children a good Christmas time.

This Esperanza associate began with us because she wants to make a business and increase their home income, and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominates the economy. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

loans.use: To buy toys and women's accessories.

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena is a married woman with four children. Three of her children attend school and one is still too young. Zena owns a house without has electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

For the past three months, Zena has operated a fish selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and other customers. In addition, she is also a farmer, which adds to her income. Zena’s major business challenge is the season, as during the rainy season it is difficult to get fish to sell. 

Zena decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 KES to purchase two deep freezers to store fish. In the future, Zena hopes to establish a permanent market stall and supply fish to hotels.

loans.use: to purchase deep freezers to store fish

loans.name: Munhtuya

texts.en:
Munhtuya N. is young lady who lives on her own with her sibling. Her parents own 200 livestock and live as a herders in the countryside in Uvs province in western Mongolia. Her sibling attends a college, majoring in carpentry. 

Munhtuya operates a hair salon in a rented room of an apartment with the help of her aunt. She started to work as a hairdresser in 2009 after graduating from Ulaangom college as a hairdresser. She and her aunt recently opened their salon in a rented space and therefore they need to remodel and decorate to their workplace. For the future, she hopes to have her own hair salon. 

Munhtuya is hardworking woman and says, "In order to open (a) big, professional hair salon, I need to work very hard at least five to six years." She is requesting a 300,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase necessary equipment and tools for her hair salon.

loans.use: To purchase necessary equipment and tools

loans.name: Seng's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of fifteen members who are taking out a village bank loan; they are located in Sambuor village in Kandal province. This village loan selected Mrs. Seng Y., a 36 year-old married woman, as the village bank president. Each member of this village will use their money for different purposes. 

Mrs. Seng Y. is a farmer who owns a plot of land which she uses to cultivate rice for a living. She would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline for growing rice. Her husband, Mr. Net Thy, is a laborer who receives a small salary to support his family.
 
This couple is working very hard with their careers to support their three children; one of whom is a laborer and the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline for growing rice.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To finish building her house and to set up a space for her store

loans.name: Grupo De Amigas Group

texts.en:
This group arose from a presentation made near the neighborhood, and it is now in the third loan cycle. They've been operating since 2010 and they've saved  2,035,349 PYG.

The director is Ms. Elvira P. of Miranda who is married and has six children. Her husband is a tradesman. Elvira works in the selling of clothes around the neighborhood as a peddler with very good results. She says that the loans given by the foundation help her buy more clothes. She is very grateful as thanks to that, she can get more income.

All the women in the group also have productive activities, like hairdressing, selling, cleaning, fruit sales, etc.

loans.use: To buy clothes and underwear for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Develop and promote her small business activity

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: La señora Juana M. R. desde hace varios años quedo viuda, por lo tanto tuvo que salir adelante para poder cubrir los gastos de la familia, aunque recibe pensión por viudez solo cubre lo indispensable. Para tener un ingreso extra Juana elabora tortillas de harina para vender en paquetes de 10 a un bajo costo, con este negocio ya 8 años al que desea comprar  mercancía para generar más ganancias.
texts.en: Sra. Juana M. R. has been a widow for several years.  She has had to move forward in order to cover the family expenses.  Juana receives a widow’s pension but it only covers the essentials.  In order to earn extra income, she makes flour tortillas and sells them in packets of 10 for a low price.  She has eight years of experience in this business and wants to buy supplies in order to generate more profits.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for making tortillas

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Нуралиев Рустам житель города Турсунзаде. Ему 30 лет. Он женат. Имеет 6 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Рустам имеет среднее образование. У него имеется хлебопекарня. Он в основном печет и продает в оптом хлеб. В этом ему помогает жена. Он берет кредит для покупки муки, чтобы производить больше хлеба и расширит свою деятельность.
texts.en: Rustam N. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. He is 30 years old. He is married and has six children. His wife is a homemaker. Rustam has secondary education and he owns a bakery. He mainly bakes bread and sells it wholesale. His wife is also helping him. He is taking out the loan to buy flour to make more bread and expand his business.

loans.use: to buy flour

loans.name: Thoi

texts.en: Thoi T. T. is 37 years old. She lives with her family in Ly nhan village. She grows rice and raises pigs for meat. Her business has lasted for long time but it is not successful. To earn more money, she made wine to sell at retail in 2008. Every day, she can make 70,000 Vietnamese dong in profits. Ms Thoi  was a client of our credit program in 2006. During that time, she was always a good re-payer and used her loans effectively. Currently, she wants to borrow 6,322,000 Vietnamese dong to buy material to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy material to make wine

loans.name: Garmai

texts.en:
Garmai is a 44-year-old married mother of eight children between the ages of 20 and 35, some whom are are still in school, but all of whom live on their own. Garmai, who was not able to go to school, lives with her husband, a cook, in Paynesville.

Garmai has a business selling oil, rice, bread, candy, other food items, and coal, an activity she has been involved in for 35 years, having learned it from her sister. She says sometimes the business is really good and all of her products move very fast, while other times it is slow. Nonetheless, she is proud of having a business that has enabled her to provide for her family.

Garmai has requested a loan to purchase coal, oil, rice and other products for her business. In the future she wants to have a house of her own that she can share with her children.

loans.use: to purchase coal, oil, rice and other products for her business.

loans.name: Maximina

texts.es:
Maximina es una madre D. familia D. 50 años D. edad, ella tiene tres hijos. Ella y su esposo viven en un caserío (comunidad rural D. condición muy pobre) ubicado en el distrito D. TambogranD. –Piura. El hogar D. Maximina no cuenta con los servicios básicos D. agua, luz y desagüe. La falta D. comodidades hace que Maximina luche por salir adelante y es por ello que se la conoce por ser una mujer trabajadora y dedicada a su familia.

La actividad que desarrolla Maximina es la crianza D. ganado ovino y vacuno, esta actividad la realiza desD. hace 6 años en corrales ubicados en la parte posterior D. su domicilio. Maximina espera que el ganado alcance tamaño y peso ideal para comercializarlo en el mercado local.

Maximina solicita un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa D. 2000 nuevos soles los que destinará en la compra D. alimento balanceado para su ganado y así lograr mayor tamaño y peso en menos tiempo, lo que la llevará a tener mayores ingresos para mejorar su calidad D. vida.

Maximina es una clienta ya conocida en Edpyme Alternativa, tiene buenos antecedentes.
texts.en:
Maxima is the mother of a family. She is 50 years old and she has three children. she and her husband live in a community (a poor rural community) located in the district of TambogranD., Piura. Maxima's home is not equipped with basic services, such as running water, hydro, or sewage. The deficiency of comforts drive Maxima to struggle to move forward and for this reason she is known to be a hardworking woman who is dedicated to her family.

Maxima's business is raising sheep and cows. She has been in the business for 6 years and her corrals are located in the rear section of her property. Maxima waits until the livestock has reached an ideal size and weight and then she sells them at the local market. 

Maxima requests a loan from Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva Field Partner) of 2000 nuevos soles to purchase balanced feed for her livestock. This will help them attain a greater size and weight in less time, which will bring her greater earnings to help her improve the quality of her life.

Maxima is a client that is known by Edpyme Alternativa and she has a good history.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed.

loans.name: Mauricia Del Socorro

texts.es:
Mauricia es del reparto la cruz, tiene su negocio ubicado en su vivienda. Tiene su negocio que es una pulpería, en donde ofrece los productos de primera necesidad. Inicio vendiendo jugos, golosinas y enlatados con el paso fue que logro ampliarse con su inventario. El noto que esto le proporcionaba muy bueno ingresos en su negocio, además que estaba en un buen punto de ventas pues transitan muchos estudiantes y todo público en general. Solicito el préstamo para comprar productos de consumo básico como arroz, frijoles, leche, huevo, carnes, pan, jugos, jabón de baño, enlatados, sopas entre otros.
Con esta inversión espera poder incrementar sus ventas, satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes, tener mejores productos alimenticios que ofrecer.
texts.en:
Mauricia is from La Cruz.  She has her business installed in her home.  Her business is a grocery store where she stocks basic need items.  She started out selling juice, snacks and canned goods and in time managed to expand her inventory.  She noticed that this produced good income plus she was well located because many students and the general public pass by her point of sales.

She asked for the loan to buy basic consumption items like: beans, rice, milk, eggs, meats, bread, juices, bath soap, canned goods and soups, among others.

With this investment she hopes to increase sales, meet customer demand and have better food items to offer.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Wilmer Wilfrido

texts.es:
Wilmer Wilfrido tiene 19 años, Es soltero vive con los padres, vive en el Cantón Ventanas Provincia de los Ríos. 

Los miembros de la V.R.C. SEÑOR DE LA SALUD, se encuentra ubicada en el Recinto Soloma, perteneciente al Cantón Echeandia, esta ventanilla se dedica a labores agrícolas de ciclo corto siembra de maíz y arroz

Wilmer se dedica a la agricultura la siembra de maíz y arroz, las compras las realiza en Ventanas y las vende en las ferias de todos los días en especial  la de los domingos.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes y abonos.  Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentar desafíos como plagas y enfermedades en los cultivos  y la variación del clima. Su sueño es comprar un terreno.

Le gusta hacer deporte.
texts.en:
Wilmer Wilfrido is 19 years old, single, and lives with his parents. He resides in the canton of Ventanas in Los Ríos Province.

The members of the Communal Bank “Señor de La Salud” (Lord of Health) meet in the neighborhood of Recinto Soloma, which is part of the canton of Echeandia. The members of this Communal Bank are short-cycle farmers who grow corn and rice.

Wilmer is a farmer who grows corn and rice. His purchases are made in Ventanas and he sells at the fairs every day, especially on Sundays.

He is requesting a loan to buy seeds, fertilizers, and compost. The support from this loan will help him financially acquire the supplies he needs. Among the challenges he faces are pests, crop diseases, and changes in weather. His dream is to buy a plot of land.

Wilmer enjoys playing sports.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and compost.

loans.name: Phelelani's Group

texts.en:
Elpha is 65 years of age, married with seven children, aged between 19 and 35, none of whom attend school. She also receives the government’s child support grant. She runs a small business selling from the pension points and in Durban, she has two employees for her business. She also takes care of  five relatives who live with her. In the photo above she is standing in the middle of her group, raising her hand.
 
Elpha has been in this business for 10 years. She requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy dye, wool, grass and buttons for decorating bags. She says that the main challenge to her business is that she has only a few employees so there is not enough customer service.

In five years' time, she would like to have her own space in the city for her business to run smoothly and to hire at least five more employees. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her pay for her children's tertiary education.
 
She appreciates WDB and Kiva for helping her with this loan.

loans.use: to buy dye, wool, grass and buttons for decorating bags.

loans.name: Gerome

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old single man from Lebanon. He is living with his parents and two siblings. In 2009, he opened a store where he started to sell a wide range of car accessories such as air fresheners, stickers, steering wheel covers etc. 

This young man was able to ably demonstrate his sales talents which allowed him to gain a good number of clients. He helps his father to meet the family's needs. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional merchandise. He is certain that the loan will help him increase his business sales which will return on him with higher profits. In the future, he is willing to open a new branch of his shop.

loans.use: to purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Blanca  Filerma

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Mujeres Organizadas. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.

La señora Blanca es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta porque los intereses son más bajos que en otras instituciones de crédito. Tiene  62 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre y de esta relación tiene 5 hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad pero la menor  aun viven con ella. Su esposo es agricultor.

Es un ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de productos Avon y Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, trabaja tres días a la semana, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana. Nos cuenta que lo que más vende son los perfumes pues son de muy buena calidad y son muy apreciados por sus clientes. Tiene tres  años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas y cosméticos.

Su sueño es seguir adelante en su negocio.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the members of the 'Mujeres Organizadas' community bank meet in Rocafuerte canton.  This place is known for the delicious sweet treats that the locals make.  They are well known throughout the country.

Blanca is a founding member of her community bank and she likes it because the interest rates are lower than those offered by other loan institutions.  Blanca is 62 years old and lives with her common-law husband.  She has five grown-up children from her relationship.  Her youngest still lives with her.  Her husband is a farmer.

Blanca is a housewife who, in order to obtain her own income, sells Avon and Yanbal products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes and ladies' accessories).  She makes her sales door to door and works three days a week.  She leaves her products on credit and collects payment every week.  She tells us that what she sells most of are the perfumes because they are very good quality and her customers like them a lot.  She has been in this business for three years and it is doing very well.

Blanca will use this loan to buy perfumes, creams and cosmetics.

Blanca's dream is to continue getting ahead in her business.

loans.use: to buy perfumes, creams and cosmetics

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia, vive con su esposo y cuatro hijos de 20, 19, 17 y 12 años de edad, ella se dedica a la crianza de cerdos, inicio junto a su esposo desde hace 10 años, inicia desde muy temprano hasta las 4:00pm.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para la compra de cerdos y alimentación (concentrado), este préstamo le ayudara para aumentar la granja y tener la alimentación deseada para un tiempo.
Espera tener un buen resultado para comercializar los cerdos, proveer para su familia lo necesario en alimentación, salud y educación y sobre todo para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Antonia lives with her husband and four children aged 20, 19, 17 and 12.  She raises pigs, a business she started together with her husband ten years ago.  She starts very early in the morning and works until 4.00pm.

Antonia is currently requesting a loan to buy pigs and feed (concentrate).  This loan will help her to expand her farm and have the feed she needs on hand.

Antonia hopes to achieve a good result so that she can sell her pigs and provide her family with everything they need as regards food, health and education, especially her children.

loans.use: to buy pigs and feed (concentrate)

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy palm-oil, palm-wine and cigarettes in bulk to add to his business.

loans.name: Hilolidin

texts.ru:
Хилолидин умный, добрый и целеустремленный человек. Он женат и ответственный молодой отец 1 ребенка. Более 2 лет он занимается услугами транспорта.  Он хочет, чтобы его сын вырос здоровым, умным и образованным. С этой целью он хочет расширить свой бизнес и получить прибыли. С прибылью он хочет отремонтировать своего дома и улучшить условия жизни. Хилолидин запрашивает займ 3000$ США для покупки запчастей для ремонта своего автомобиля. Он заранее благодарит всех кредиторов за поддержку и поощрение. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en: Hilolidin is a smart, kind and goal-oriented person.  He is married and is a responsible young father of one child.  He has been involved in transportation service for over two years.  He wants his son to grow up healthy, smart and educated.  With this goal in mind, he wants to expand his business and make a profit.  He wants to then use the profit to make repairs to his house and improve his living conditions.  Hilolidin is requesting a loan in the sum of $3000 for the purchase of auto parts to repair his car.  He thanks all creditors in advance for the help and support.

loans.use: to purchase auto parts to repair his car

loans.name: Irene

texts.es: Irene, de 21 años, es una joven madre de familia. Vive en concubinato con Miguel, con quien desea formar una familia consolidada pues esperan a su primer hijo. Ambos viven en su casa propia, ubicada en el caserío de Bellavista Huaracayo. Ya tiene 7 meses de embarazo y espera con muchas ansias a su primer hijo. Por eso trabaja desde hace 3 años es “la agricultura”, sus principales sembríos constan de alverjas, papa y habas, los cuales siembra en un terreno que alquila en la zona de Santa Fe. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es poder pasar la mayor parte de su tiempo junto a sus hermanos, pues le ayudan en el cuidado de sus cultivos. Según menciona en temporadas de cosecha, se turnan para poder trasladar sus alimentos al mercado mayorista de la ciudad; donde comercializan obteniendo buenas ganancias. Además concreto sus planes, pues siempre soñaba con tener un negocio propio, ahora vende combustible en la entrada al pueblo de Santa fe, donde hay mucha demanda. Con su dinero extra podrá brindar a su futuro hijo la comodidad que ella nunca tubo. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Señor de Muruhuay”, y este es el tercer crédito con MFP, donde se siente agradecida por el apoyo que recibe constantemente. Razón por la que promete ser puntual en sus cuotas. Irene de recibir su apoyo; invertirá el dinero solicitado en la comprar 3 arrobas de semilla de maíz y 2 bolsas de semilla de alverja de la variedad “super”, con esto se prepara para su próxima siembra.
texts.en:
Irene is 21, and a housewife. She is in a common-law relationship with Miguel, with whom she wants to form a close-knit family, as they are expecting their first child. They live in their own home, located in the rural settlement of Bellavista Huaracayo. She is already 7 months pregnant, and is anxiously awaiting the birth of her first child. 

That's why she has been farming for 3 years, growing mainly peas, potatoes, and fava beans, which she grows on land she rents in the Santa Fe area. What she likes best about her work is to be able to spend most of her time with her brothers, as they help her look after her crops. She says that at harvest times, they take turns transporting their produce to the wholesale market in the city, where they sell it at a good profit.

In addition, she described her plans. As she has always dreamed of having her own business, she now sells fuel at the entrance to the town of Santa Fe, where there is a lot of demand.

With her extra money, she will be able to offer her future child the comforts she never had. She belongs to the "Señor de Muruhuay" communal bank, and this is her third loan from MFP.  She is grateful for the support that she constantly gets there, and this is why she promises to make her payments on time. Irene will use the money she is applying for to buy 75 lb. of corn, and 2 bags of seed for growing "Super" variety peas. With this, she'll be ready for her next planting.

loans.use: To buy 75 lb. of corn, and 2 bags of seed for growing peas.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is 65 years old, married, and has one child.  She lives in the Philippines. Rosita has a shop that sells green and yellow bananas and coconuts. She has had this business for five years. Rosita is requesting a loan for 4,000 PHP, which she will use to buy bananas and coconuts.

Rosita has been a member of HSPFI since 2008. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase bananas and coconuts.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to improve her home (building and rendering walls)

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is 28 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with five children. 
Ester has a shop where she sells fish like sardines and mackerel. She has had this business for 10 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 14,000 to buy more fish to sell.
Ester has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Ester hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Baye Niass

texts.fr: L'emprunteur est un jeune marié sans enfants.Il a arrété ses études depuis deux ans faute de moyens pour les prendre en charge.Il s'est alors lancé dans le commerce de cartes de recharge téléphonique, un secteur qui marche fort en ce moment. Ses revenus lui permettent de subvenir assez correctement à ses besoins et à ceux de son épouse. Pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, il sollicite un pret de 250000f pour acheter un stock de cartes orange, tigo et expresso.Son ambition est de s'implanter en pleine ville dans sa propre cantine.
texts.en: This borrower is a young married man who has no children. He abandoned his studies two years ago as he did not have the means to pay for them. He then launched himself into the sale of telephone recharge cards, a business sector which is currently performing well. His income enables him to provide reasonably for his and his wife's needs. In order to expand his business, he is requesting a loan of 250,000 francs so that he can buy a stock of Orange, Tigo and Expresso cards. His ambition is to be able to set up his own store in the centre of town.

loans.use: to buy a stock of Orange, Tigo and Expresso cards

loans.name: Carmela

texts.es: Carmela, D. 47 años, es una mujer amable, buena y muy trabajadora, ella esta casada hace muchos años y es madre D. tres hijos D. los cuales dos ya son mayores e independientes. Ahora vive en compañía D. su esposo e hijo D. 12 años en su casa propia, trabaja mucho y arduo para así brindarle lo mejor a su hijo quien aún depenD. D. ella, mientras que su esposo ayuda para los estudios y su alimentación. El trabajo D. Carmela consiste en realizar dos actividades, primero es la administración económica D. dos moto taxis que posee, y por las tarD. se dedica a vender comida. Sin embargo éste último trabajo no lo esta ejerciendo por ahora, solo el fin D. semana, venD. en la esquina D. su casa, parrilladas. Tiene 15 años trabajando en esta actividad, y hasta el momento le ha generado ingresos. Por otro lado, ella es profesora D. educación primaria y labora en una institución educativa D. la ciudad. Le esta yendo bien ya que a diario tiene ganancias. y su sueldo como docente lo utiliza para los gastos mensuales D. su casa. Espera poder tener una venta D. repuestos en su casa ya que su hijo sabe mucho D. mecánica y le gustaría ayudarlo con éste negocio. Este será el quinto crédito con la institución MFP, le esta yendo bien en su grupo ya que son muy responsables, espera seguir trabajando bien y con la puntualidad que le caracteriza. Esta muy agradecida con los préstamos recibidos anteriormente. Con el monto solicitado, comprará equipos D. video juego, ya que iniciará un nuevo negocio, que consistirá en el alquiler D. video juegos.
texts.en: Carmela, 47, is a good, hardworking and friendly woman.  She has been married for many years, and she is the mother of 3 children, two of whom are adult and independent.  She is now lives with her husband and 12 year-old son in her own home.  She works very hard to proviD. the best for her son who is still dependent upon her, while her husband helps to proviD. for his education and food.  Carmela has two economic activities.  She manages a business with 2 moto-taxis that she owns, and in the afternoons she sells food.  However, she does this second business only on the weekends, selling barbequed meat from the corner of her house.  She has been doing this type of work for 15 years, and up until now it has generated income for her.  In addition, she is a primary school teacher, and she works in an educational institute in the city.  This is going well, and gives her daily earnings; she uses the salary she earns as a teacher to pay for the monthly household expenses.  She hopes to be able to have a business selling spare parts from her house, since her son knows a lot about mechanics, and would like to help her with this business.  This will be the 5th loan  that she has taken with MFP, and it is going well because her group members are very responsible.  She expects that they will continue to work well together, and that the members will continue to be punctual with their payments as they have in the past.  She is very grateful for the loans that she received previously.  With the sum she requests she will buy video game equipment, since she plans to start a new business renting out video games.

loans.use: to buy video game equipment

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac is a 32-year-old married man with three children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. He owns a charcoal store and has been operating it for six years. He has limited capital to expand his business and high transport costs involved in transportation of charcoal from the suppliers. His personal goals include educating his children and constructing a permanent house. He also wants to expand his charcoal business to operate on a large scale and diversify his business. Isaac wants money to purchase charcoal.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children who are all currently in school. For the past 1 year, Rose has been working hard to manage her hotel, which sells food. 

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food for cooking for resale, and will help Rose to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Rose hopes that in the future she will be able to own a taxi vehicle. 

Rose is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Rose's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy food to cook for resale

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora, 51 years of age, is married to Loreto and works as a farmer. Aurora is engaged in selling different products in their community. She would do anything for the benefit of her family. Aurora is requesting a loan of P 50,000 to purchase coffee, noodles, drinks, shampoo, and soap for her sari-sari store (community-based store).

Aurora hopes that someday she can provide for all the needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of products such as drinks, noodles, coffee, shampoo, and soap for her store

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson is a 46 year-old farmer. He is married and blessed with three children. He wants to yield abundant income through his business but, because of his obligations to traders who have high interest rates, he was not be able to save enough for his family as well as his business.  Therefore, to avoid having debts to traders with high rates, he is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 from Alalay sa Kaunlaran Inc., which would allow him to purchase farm supplies such as seeds, fertilizers and insecticides to improve his business.

He is very thankful because he can provide the essential plant care for his rice crops. Hopefully, he can gain high income so that he can support his youngest child to pursue his studies.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies, such as seeds, fertilizers and insecticides to improve his business

loans.name: Emelda

texts.en: Emelda 49 years old and the single mother of a twenty-four-year-old daughter. She is an honest and efficient woman. She runs a grocery store and sells fruits such as apples, bananas, mangoes and watermelons. She has been in this business for eleven years. She has three employees. Her business challenge is shortages of stock. She will be using the loan of Kes 20,000 to renovate her business premises. Emelda's hope and dream is to run a restaurant and to provide rental house services in the next five years.

loans.use: To renovate her business premises.

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.es:
Wilfredo tiene 42 años de edad, vive en la ciudad de Ica, conocida como “ la tierra del sol Eterno”, ya que siempre se puede disfrutar del sol en cualquier época del año, asimismo también por sus danzas típicas y por la “Laguna de Huacachina” conocida como  “el oasis de América” y sobre todo porque es una ciudad donde los pobladores son muy hospitalarios y generosos, además de ser optimistas ya que a pesar del terremoto sucedido en el año 2007 en el cual muchos pobladores perdieron la vida y quedaron damnificados, los pobladores salieron adelante. El Perú es muy conocido también por su deliciosa comida y uno de los platos que le gusta mucho a Wilfredo es el delicioso “Arroz con Pollo”, consiste en: arroz combinado con pollo, en presas o mechado, verduras (maíz desgranado, zanahoria en cubos, judías) y otras especias.

Wilfredo se dedica a su labor de cerrajero que consiste en reparar las cerraduras de puertas, reparación de candados, fabricación de llaves, él le dedica a su trabajo alrededor de 10 horas diarias en las cuales a pesar del intenso calor que hay en la ciudad el se desempeña com mucha fuerza, atiende alrededor de 10 clientes diariamente y puede ganar hasta S/.380 y en un día muy bueno puede ganar hasta S/. 500, 
El cree que le va bien en su negocio debido a que realiza una buena labor y sobre todo que es empeñoso al hacerla, además de atender a los clientes de manera amable.

Wilfredo está muy agradecido con el apoyo de los prestatarios Kiva ya que gracias a este apoyo el podrá comprar más herramientas y materiales y mejorar su taller de cerrajeria para la realización de su trabajo, con esta mejora tendrá mas materiales y realizara aun mejor su trabajo y tener un taller mas equipado, con ello obtendrá mas ingresos para si poder seguir ahorrando y poder cumplir su gran sueño: “Tener una empresa de servicios”.
texts.en:
Wilfredo, 42, lives in the city of Ica, known as The Land of the Eternal Sun because you can always enjoy the sun in any season of the year.  It is also known for its traditional dances and for the Huacachina Lagoon, known as The Oasis of America, and above all as a city whose residents are welcoming and generous as well as optimistic since they came out ahead in spite of the 2007 earthquake in which many lost their lives or were injured.  Peru is well known also for the delicious food, and one of the dishes that Wilfredo likes very much is the delicious chicken and rice, which has rice combined with chicken, in pieces or stuffed, vegetables (corn kernels, diced carrot, green beans), and other spices.

Wilfredo works at his job as a locksmith, which consists of repairing door locks, repairing padlocks, and making keys.  He works about 10 hours a day, which he does with great effort despite the intense heat in his city.  He waits on around 10 customers a day and can earn up to 380 PEN, and 500 PEN in a very good day.  He believes that his business is going well for him because he does a good job and above all he is hardworking in doing it.  He also takes care of the customers in a pleasant way.

Wilfredo is very grateful for the support of the Kiva lenders because thanks to this help he will be able to buy more tools and materials to improve his locksmith shop to do his work.  With this improvement he will have more materials and will do an even better job and have a better equipped shop.  With this he will get more income so he will be able to continue saving and be able to realize his biggest dream, to have a service enterprise.

loans.use: to buy tools and materials.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has three children and of whom go to school. She has no additional family members. She sells bananas at the market on retail basis. She also has rental rooms and piped water. She has been in business for the last eight years. She works seven days a week. 

Joyce has requested a loan of 600,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy more bunches of bananas. Her major challenge is transportation. Her aspiration is to expand into the wholesale business .She lives in her own house and her family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and monthly market dues.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas.

loans.name: God Will Provide Group

texts.en:
Isaac, age 74, is a member of God Will Provide group. He is happily married with six children. His youngest child is still attending school. Isaac lives with his family in Efutu Koforidua in the Central Region of Ghana. 

Isaac has been a farmer for the past 20 years and has gained much experience. He grows oranges and cocoa on two separate farms. Isaac is an enterprising and hardworking man, however age is tearing on him to maintain the farm alone.

He belongs to farming association that facilitates price negotiations and marketing of their crops.    Now, Isaac only needs to maximize his output.

His hurdle is how to find financial assistance to finance the cost of  maintaining his farms. He has to pay for  hired labourers to weed the farm, prune the trees and harvest the fruits.  A micro-loan of GHC1,000 will assist  Isaac pay for  the manual labor he needs. Isaac will use the gains from the farm to pay for his last child's school fees and support his family.

Isaac thanks all his  micro-lenders for their generous assistance.

loans.use: to hire labourers for weeding, pruning, and harvesting

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose aged 47 years. She is married with three children aged between 12 and 20 years. They all go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 23 years. While her husband is a business man. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a goat. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.en:
Mr. V. was born on October 13, 1973 in Lomé, in the prefecture of Golf. Having not been able to continue his studies, he has been trained in high fashion design, for which he has demonstrated success. Married without children for the moment, he is living with three (03) dependents. He is the design master with 27 apprentices of whom 23 are young girls. Very social, calm and cool, he is a likable man and appreciated in his suburb and in the area. Also generous and charitable, he is training some girls in his workshop for free, and helps out with some of his apprentices\\\\\\\' needs like health care and lunch in the centre. His workshop is well attended and his machines are sufficient to respond to the current demand, considering the very high number of the apprentices. He plans now to acquire additional sewing machines and to undertake haberdashery trade near his workshop. This expansion of his activities requires a credit of $850, allowing him to acquire the two sewing machines and haberdashery articles.

M. V. est né le 13 octobre 1973 à Lomé, dans la préfecture du golfe. N’ayant pas eu la chance de poursuivre ses études, il s’est fait former en haute coouture qu’il exerce impeccablement aujourd’hui. Marié sans enfant pour le moment, il a pourtant à trois personnes à sa charge. Il est maître tailleur avec 27 d’apprentis dont 23 jeunes filles. Très sociable et plus féministe, son air très calme et sa patience font de lui, un homme très aimé et apprécié dans son entourage et dans le quartier. Aussi généreux que charitable, il forme gratuitement dans son atelier certaines filles très nécessiteuses et subvient à certains besoins de ses apprenties comme la santé et la déjeuner au centre. Son atelier est très bien fréquenté et ses machines sont insuffisantes pour répondre aux exigences du moment vu le nombre très élevé d’apprentis. Il prévoit alors d’acquérir des machines à coudre complémentaires et d’entreprendre le commerce de mercerie (vente de tissus et des articles de couture) à côté de son atelier. Cette extension de ses activités nécessite des moyens financiers de $ 850 lui permettant d’acquérir les deux machines à coudre et les articles de la mercerie

loans.use: To buy two sewing machines and haberdashery articles

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is married with a teenage son. In post-Soviet times many families in Ukraine struggled to meet their basic needs. Tatyana’s family was no exception. She decided to start her own business selling groceries to help provide for her family during those tough times. Some of the first loans Tatyana received from “Nadiya Ukraine” were very small. She was able to maintain a perfect credit history and gradually could borrow greater amounts as her business grew. With time her hard work and determination paid off and Tatyana began to witness rapid growth in sales and the expansion of her business. Eventually she was able to open a new kiosk selling clothing and women’s lingerie and hired people to help her with sales. Currently, Tatyana has about $1,200 in monthly net profit. Tatyana is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy more stock to sell in her women’s clothing and lingerie store. She would like to purchase assorted sweaters, skirts, blouses, and good quality underwear to meet growing demand from her customers. The loan will help Tatyana strengthen her trade activities and provide necessary resources for her business and family.

Тетяна – одружена, в неї є син підліток. В пострадянські часи багатьом родинам довелося зіткнутися з численними побутовими труднощами. Родина Тетяни не стала винятком. Отже, Тетяна вирішила почати власний бізнес з продажу товарів харчування для того, щоб забезпечити себе й рідних в ті скрутні часи. Перші позики, які Тетяна отримала від «Надії України» були зовсім невеличкими. Її кредитна історія була чудовою, отже, вона змогла отримати більші за розміром позики. З часом її наполеглива праця та цілеспрямованість принесли свої результати. Бізнес Тетяни швидко зростав та обсяги продажів ставали дедалі більшими. Врешті-решт вона змогла відкрити новий кіоск з продажу жіночого одягу та білизни та взяти на роботу реалі- заторів. Сьогодні Тетяна заробляє приблизно 1200 доларів чистого прибутку щомісяця. Тетяна просить про позику в 1200 доларів для того, щоб придбати більше одиниць жіночого одягу та білизни. Вона планує придбати светри, спідниці, блузи та якісну білизну для того, щоб задовольнити зростаючий попит своїх клієнтів. Позика допоможе Тетяні зміцнити торгівлю та забезпечить необхідні ресурси для родини та бізнесу.

loans.use: To increase clothing stock

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio is from the county of Baba, a rice-growing region on the Ecuadorian coast. Antonio has lived in Baba since he was born there 70 years ago. He has a rice farm where he, his wife, Paula, and several of their children work together to harvest the product. He is very happy that he is still a leader in his family and that he can help them earn a living. He wants to invest in fertilizer and pesticides for the rice, products which will make his lands more productive.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Antonio es del canton Baba, un sector arrocero en la costa ecuatoriana. Antonio ha vivido en Baba desde que nacio hace 70 años. El tiene arroz en su finca donde el, su esposa Paula y varios de sus hijos trabajan en conjunto para cosechar el producto. El esta bien feliz que todavía es un lider en su familia y les puede ayudar sobrevivir. El quiere invertir en fertilizante y pesticidas para el arroz, productos que le harán mas productivas sus tierras y para que tenga mas rendimiento.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Rosa de Oro (Golden Rose) Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Rosa de Oro helps the farmers by providing access to machinery, training services and government assistance. The farmers from Rosa de Oro are very close to each other and cooperate to help one another on their farms.

The members of Rosa de Oro will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Rosa de Oro Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Baba

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: To invest in rice

loans.name: Laide

texts.en: Laide A. is 32 years old and a mother of two children. She lives in Adjamé, a commercial township north of Abidjan. She has more than ten years of work experience in selling fashion products, especially body lotions, sprays etc. She is very dynamic and ambitious.  A. received her first from AE&I in October 2004 and has been a good performer so far. She requests the loan in order to develop her business and increase her revenue.

loans.use: Laide Aloyola will use the loan to purchase goods in bulk.

loans.name: Paulino Joao

texts.pt:
Married, with 6 children, Paulino João entered the program in 2006, with a loan of 3000 meticais. As his business evolved, growing gradually, in September he would like to take out a loan of 12,000 meticais. With the profits of the business, he will invest in items for his home, and in the future, he plans to improve his home.

Translated from Portuguese by a Kiva volunteer.

Casado, 6 filhos entrou para o programa em 2006, com um emprestimo de 3.000mts com a evolucaodo negocio foi subindo gradualmente. no dia 2/9 tomou 12.000mts, com os lucros do negocio tem investido em bens domesticos, no futuro pensa melhorar a sua casa.

loans.use: Purchase roosters and feed

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Mrs. Bridget I. is 55 years old. She sells wrappers and jewelery and lives in Benin City. She is married with 6 children, and she started her business in 1986. She will be glad if the loan of $400 is given to her, to enable her to buy more wrappers & jewelery. She is a faithful member of LAPO.

loans.use: To buy more wrappers & jewelery

loans.name: Maria Elsa

texts.es:
This woman is originally from Chinandega city. Her business is located in the Bisne market. She began two years ago with a modest amount of capital, only C$1500 córdobas (US$80), from her savings.

She decided to start this business, beginning with a few products, selling candy from a table and basket. As fruit of this labor and perserverance with great sacrifice she was able to acquire her permanent location.

She now offers a wide variety of products, although always on a small scale. The first loand she asked for from CEPRODEL, was for C$1500 córdobas and she has been working for more than one year (as she was still selling from the street), with a history of 5 payments. Thanks to CEPRODEL she has been able to increase her inventory and earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Esta señora es originaria de la ciudad de Chinandega. Su negocio esta ubicado en el mercado el bisne. Empieza hace más de 2 años con un modesto capital de trabajo de apenas C$ 1,500 córdobas (U$$ 80 dólares), fruto de sus ahorros.

Ella decide iniciar dicho negocio, el cual al principio contaba con algunos productos, vendia golosinas en una mesa y una canasta. Como fruto de su esfuerzo y perseverancia con mucho sacrificio logró adquirir su local.

Ella ahora oferta una amplia variedad de productos,aunque siempre menor escala. El primer crédito que le otorgó CEPRODEL, fue de C$ 1,500 córdobas con quien tiene más de 1 año de trabajar (desde que aún vendía en la calle), con un récord de 5 creditos. Gracias a CEPRODEL ha logrado incrementar su inventario y sus ganancias.

loans.use: Purchase products

loans.name: Uamsho B Group

texts.en:
Halima, age 35, is married with 4 children (ages 14, 10, 6 and 1). She owns a business of selling wood, which she began about a year ago. Everyday, she sells wood from 8am to 4pm. In a month, she makes about $132 in profit from this business.

Halima is the leader of subgroup Uamsho B. She will be sharing this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in food, charcoal, and general items sales.

loans.use: To buy wood stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add to her business inventory and stock

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
Charlotte M. is 32 years old, married to a carpenter, and has 2 children. She is a businesswoman who sells drinks. She is requesting a loan of $425 to buy drinks in bulk at a discount. 90+ degree weather, year-round, makes for many thirsty Ghanaians.

Charlotte is also a member of a lending group called “Calvary Group”, which consists of 11 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To drinks in bulk at a discount for re-sale

loans.name: Ada's Group

texts.es:
The group is made up of 15 women from the company Cabañas in the city of Caacupé, Paraguay. They are enterprising, hard-working women dedicated to wide-spread activities, but that doesn't effect the good organization of the group.

Currently, the women are in their seventh loan cycle in the Committee of Enterprising Women program and each member has a line of credit. The group started after some initial informational meetings in the home Ninfa Vázquez, who learned of the program from a cousin who's a member in another group. Thanks to the meetings, the women started to mobilize and soon they were able to form a group of 15, the minimum requisite number. Today they are ready for their eighth loan cycle.

Ada A., president of the committee, says it was a little difficult to reach a consensus on how to divide the first loans among the members — there were always differing opinions. But as time went on their relationship strengthened, and today one of the characteristics of the group is the harmony and mutual respect they have for each other. She considers the group's success comes from the fact that each member must meet the objectives as an individual and as a group.

Among the activities that these women participate in are: selling plants, selling crafts, a convenience store, a kiosk, selling clothes, and the majority are dedicated to selling "chipas" — a very popular traditional dish in Paraguay. To invest in these different business, the women are requesting a loan which they plan to repay monthly and punctually.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

El comité está integrado por 15 señoras trabajadoras de la compañía Cabañas de la ciudad de Caacupé; el grupo esta compuesto por mujeres emprendedoras que se dedican a actividades diversas, pero esto no influye negativamente en la buena coordinación del grupo.

Actualmente ellas están en el 7to. Ciclo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y manejan una línea de crédito promedio de Gs. 713.000 por cada integrante. El comité se inició con unas primeras reuniones informativas que se realizaron en la casa de la señora Ninfa Vázquez, quién tuvo conocimiento del programa a través de una prima que es integrante de otro grupo.

Gracias a las reuniones informativas, las señoras empezaron a movilizarse y en corto tiempo lograron juntar 15 señoras que es el requisito mínimo para formar el comité. Hoy día ellas ya están listas para pasar al 8vo ciclo de renovación.

Ada A., presidenta del comité, manifiesta que en los primeros ciclos fue un poco difícil llegar a consensuar entre todas, siempre había opiniones dispares, no obstante a medida que fue pasando el tiempo el grupo se fue fortaleciendo y hoy una de las características de este comité es la armonía y el respeto mutuo entre todas, y considera que le éxito de un comité se da por la sencilla razón de que cada integrante debe estar comprometido con los objetivos que se han trazado en forma individual y como integrante del grupo.

Entre las actividades que desarrollan estas mujeres están: venta de plantas, ventas de artesanías en barro, despensas, kioscos, venta de ropas, y la mayoría se dedica a la venta de “chipas” comida típica muy consumida en el Paraguay. Para invertir en estos diferentes negocios, estas mujeres solicitan el crédito que se comprometen a pagar mensualmente de forma puntual.

loans.use: To purchase items like oil, cookies, sugar, cotton, cheese, vegetable oil, firewood, flour, milk, clothing, seeds, fertilizer, etc. / Para la compra de mercaderías tales como aceite, galletas, azúcar, almidón, queso, aceite vegetal, leña, harina, leche, ropas para niños, damas, caballeros, semillas, abono, entre otros.

loans.name: Brigida's Group

texts.es:
Sonia and Brígida have been members of the Communal Artisan Bank for 6 months and one year, respectively. They are from the Huascahura District, 30 minutes from the city of Ayacucho.

Sonia is a 24-year-old single mother with two children. Sonia weaves fabrics and blankets that she sells in the city of Lima. Sonia also sells cheeses and meats in the city of Lima.

Brígida is 43 and married with one child. She has a store where she sells groceries and produce. Additionally, Brígida sells meat that she distributes house-to-house in Ayacucho.

Sonia and Brígida will divide loan proceeds to invest in wool, dyes, pasta, rice, sugar and oil.

Sonia and Brígida dream of building a house, improving their businesses, and educating their children.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

Sonia y Brígida pertenecen al Banco Comunal Artesanos hace 6 meses y 1 año respectivamente. Ellas son del Distrito de Huascahura a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Sonia es madre soltera, tiene 24 años y 2 hijos, Sonia realiza tejidos en telar como individuales, frazadas que vende en la ciudad de Lima. Además Sonia vende quesos y carne en la ciudad de Lima.

Mientras que Brígida es casada, tiene 43 años y 1 hijo, Brígida tiene una tienda donde vende abarrotes, verduras. Además Brígida vende carne que reparte de casa en casa en la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Sonia y Brígida necesitan préstamos de 900 soles cada una, dinero que será invertido en la compra de lana, tinte, fideo, arroz, azúcar, aceite.

Los sueños de Sonia y Brígida son construir su casa, mejorar sus negocios y sus hijos estudien.

loans.use: Purchase of wool, dyes, pasta, rice, sugar and oil

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary O. sells goods such as rice, beans, yam, and corn. Mary's husband is a carpenter and they have one child.

Business is going very well and she would like to expand the business by using a loan to purchase a larger inventory of goods.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for sale to increase her business and profits

loans.name: Zulma

texts.es:
Mrs. Zulma Beatriz Ruiz D. is from the Ycua Paí neighborhood in the city of San Estanislao. She is a 33-year-old woman who is married to Mr. Dario Asunción Rojas, age 38. They have 4 children.

Zulma has a general store called “Panamby” which means “butterfly” in Guaraní. The store is located in her home and has been in business for 8 years, with a solid client-base and a good selection of merchandise.
