The business is frequented by the residents of the area who always purchase Zulma’s provisions.

Zulma is currently saving up money with which she would like to build a bigger space for her general store, thus expanding her business and offering a wider selection of goods. She would now like to obtain a loan to purchase goods for her general store so that she can increase her profits and later be able to expand her business space.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Zulma Beatriz Ruiz D. es de la ciudad de San Estanislao del Barrio Ycua Paí, tiene 33 años de edad, esta casada con el señor Dario Asunción Rojas de 38 años de edad y tienen 4 hijos.

Zulma tiene una despensa llamada “Panamby” que en guaraní significa mariposa, la misma esta ubicada en su propia casa, tiene 8 años de funcionamiento, con buena clientela y un buen stock de mercaderías. El negocio es muy concurrido por los vecinos de la zona que siempre van a surtirse de cosas en su despensa.

Zulma actualmente está juntando unos ahorros con el que desea construir un salón más grande para su despensa y de este modo expandir el negocio y variar las mercaderías que vende. Hoy día tiene pensado adquirir con el crédito mercaderías para su despensa para aumentar sus ingresos y luego poder cumplir su sueño de construir un salón.

loans.use: Purchase cleaning supplies, fruits, vegetables, canned goods, sugar, flour, milk, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Crispino

texts.es:
Crispino is 47 years old and married to Leoncia Bogado. He has five children, 3 of whom are older and 2 younger.

From a very young age, Crispino worked with his father in a carpentry shop where he learned how to be a carpenter. With the help of his wife who works in a diner, he was able to establish a carpentry shop from his home.

Crispino needs a loan to buy raw materials in bulk such as wood, nails, and glue, among others. In the future he would like to buy a vehicle to transport his work rather than paying to transport loads.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Crispino tiene 47 años esta casado con la señora Leoncia Bogado, tienen 5 hijos 3 mayores de edad y 2 menores.

Crispino desde muy joven trabajo con su padre en una carpintería en donde aprendió el oficio de carpintero, con la ayuda de su esposa que trabaja en un copetín pudo montar su carpintería en su domicilio.

Necesita este crédito para la compra de materiales en cantidad tales como maderas, clavos, pegamento, entre otros. En el futuro desea comprar un vehiculo para transportar sus trabajos y no pagar fletes.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials such as wood, nails, glue for wood, paints and finishes, etc.

loans.name: Ni Komang Sriani

texts.id:
Melalui  organisasi Tempek ( sebuah organisasi adat ) yang ada didesanya, Ni  Komang Sriani mendapatkan dana dari Yayasan DINARI untuk periode ke dua. Pinjaman pertama dirasakan sangat membantu usahanya, karena ingin mengembangkan usahanya, Ni Komang Sriani mengajukan permohonan untuk mendapatkan pinjaman yang kedua.  Dana tersebut sangat berarti dalam menambah modal usaha dalam usaha jual beli hasil pertanian. Dalam sehari Ni Komang Sriani dapat membeli coklat, pisang, kelapa dan hasil kebun lainnya. Esok paginya, Ni Komang Sriani akan menjualnya barang dagangannya dipasar ataupun beberapa pelanggan yang biasa membeli darinya. Keuntungan bersih dalam setiap hari dapat mencapai Rp. 25.000.- s/d 30.000.- 
Dari Usaha seperti inilah Komang Sriani dapat menggantungkan hidupnya bersama suaminya, Darma Kantun, yang tidak bekerja dan hanya mengandalkan hasil kebunnya sendiri.

loans.use: Menambah modal usaha

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia A. operates a local restaurant where she sells a variety of local dishes such as fufu which is made out of cassava and plantains pounded together and other dishes at Kodadwen in Cape Coast. Cecilia has received Junior High level education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a tailor.

Cecilia has been operating this small local restaurant since 2008. She is responsible for helping her husband in the payment of the children's school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more ingredients, spices and food items for the food preparation at her restaurant. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to help her husband to start putting up a house for the family.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients, spices and food items for food preparation

loans.name: Mirna Del Socorro

texts.es: Inicio su negocio ofreciendo sopas, gracias a un crédito, ofrecido  por  ADIM  logro  fortalecer su negocio ofreciendo cabeza de cerdo, morongas, comidas rápidas, indio viejo, refrescos entre otros. La actividad la realiza en su misma casa, trabaja de lunes a domingo. Doña Mirna vive con dos hijas quienes estudian y a la vez  cooperan con la preparación de los alimentos. Sueña con llegar a  tener una soda  con un local propio ofreciendo variedad de comidas.Plazo otorgado 4 meses.
texts.en:
Mirna started her business by making and selling soups. Thanks to a loan from ADIM, she was able to grow her business and now offers other food such as pork, sausages, snacks and cold drinks. She runs this business from her home, working Mondays through Sundays. Mirna lives with her two daughters who study at school, as well as help prepare the meals. Mirna's goal is to have her own location one day where she can offer a wide variety of food. She will repay the loan in 4 months.


Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in her food business and one day open a larger location

loans.name: Ren

texts.en: Mrs. Ren M. is a 47-year-old villager in Si Sla village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer cultivates rice and breeds pigs. Her husband, Mr. Leng Ly, is cyclo driver. they have five children, two of whom are fisherM. while the three others attend the local school. Mrs. Ren M. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make her rice paddy more productive and to buy four piglets for breeding.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and piglets

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
“I am a mother who has big dreams for my child”, says Julieta A., a 38-year-old mother from Butuan City, Agusan Del Norte. She aspires to having a simple, happy family life. Having little to provide for her family's needs, she worries where to get money to send her children to school.  

Her desire to help with the family expenses encourages her to have her own store, where she sells a variety of goods to her neighbors. She is requesting a loan to purchase additional stock and items to sell. By doing this, she believes she will earn a bigger income.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret I. is 48 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a retired civil servant. She sells yams in wholesale and retail. She hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is requesting a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more yams to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell

loans.name: María Luisa

texts.es:
La elaboración de tortillas es un digno negocio al que se dedica gran parte de las mujeres en Nicaragua y en este caso la señora María Luisa M. se dedica a realizar unas deliciosas tortillas en la ciudad de León el cual son comercializadas por ella misma y así mantiene a su familia compuesta por sus dos pequeños hijos ya que por ser madre soltera hace el papel de padre y madre a la vez.

El motive por el que ella ha acudido a Ceprodel es para solicitar un crédito con el cual comprar la materia prima principal como es el maíz para luego molerlo y así elaborar las tortillas que tanto agradan a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Tortilla making is a good business, and one in which many women in Nicaragua work. María Luisa M. makes delicious tortillas which she markets herself in the city of León. This is how she, as a single mother playing the role of both father and mother at once, supports her two small children. She came to Ceprodel to request a loan with which to buy raw materials -- mainly corn, which she grinds and then uses to make the tortillas that are so pleasing to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Hannah Lily, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing corn

loans.name: Ana Riza

texts.en:
Ana Riza F. She is 29-years old, has two children, and owns a "Basak", a Filipino term for rice field. She grows rice and uses her harvest for family consumption. What her family doesn't need is sold to rice traders in their village  to augment their income. Formally, she worked as a "saleslady" or person who traded products inside the malls and department stores. She has been a CEVI client for two years and has a good repayment records.

She is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers and other farm inputs. The loan will help her increase her yield and have more rice to sell.  

CEVI helps Ana Riza grow her business. She is provided with credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farm inputs for the farm

loans.name: Enh-Amgalan

texts.en: Enh-Amgalan G. is a married man who lives with his family in Hentiy, one of Mongolia's southern provinces. During the last 10 years, he has been running a furniture business. He makes doors for "gers" (Mongolian traditional nomadic housing), tables, beds, iron stoves and stove chimneys. There is high demand for these products as many Mongolians continue to live in traditional gers, heating them with small coal stoves against the frigid winter nights. He has many repeat customers as his furniture is well built. With his profits from the last 10 years, he has purchased his own plot of land, bought new furniture for his home and purchased a motorcycle. Since he needs more room for his business, he is planning to build a store this year on the land he owns. "My life condition is well improved because of my business success. My wife and I are planning to have our own big house in the future," Enh-Amgalan said in Mongolian.

loans.use: To buy wood

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys N. is 53 years old and married with a child. She sells provisions. She is requesting the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is married and has four children. She has received schooling through junior high school. Mary is a trader who sells corn, groundnuts and millet at Akotokyir in Abura, which she has done since 1992. Her husband works as a sanitation officer.

Mary uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses. She will use the loan to purchase additional bags of millet, corn and groundnut paste for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to build a house and expand her enterprise.

loans.use: To purchase additional bags of millet, corn and groundnut paste for resale

loans.name: Wdah

texts.en: Wdah A. is 50 years old, and is married with 3 children. Despite not having finished his basic education, Wdah always had the vision and the hope of running his own business. After years of effort and work, he was able to open a small restaurant on one of the main streets of his neighborhood. Now it has started to grow. He is requesting a loan to purchase materials needed to expand his business, and continue to improve his personal and economic situation.

loans.use: Purchase materials needed to expand his business

loans.name: Porferia

texts.en:
" Before, my family suffered from financial difficulties. Now, at least  we have a farm that we use to supply our daily needs. Now we are busy preparing the farm for our next planting. My wish is that we will again have an abundant harvest and good weather conditions" says Porferia D., a mother of three children.

She requests a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI, which she will use to purchase Urea  and complete fertilizers, herbicides, and other farm inputs. 

CEVI has been providing financial services to rural communities. CEVI provides  loans as well as training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase Urea  and complete fertlizers, herbicides, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Bahriddin

texts.en:
Bahriddin is a responsible father of 5 children. From the time he was a boy, he learned the honorable work of raising livestock, activities which were passed down from his parents and which today bring him satisfaction. Thanks to his valuable knowledge of the livestock trade, he has been able to obtain good results from his sales. This enterprising gentleman’s wish is to invest more capital in young animals. Bahriddin hopes to continue his dedication to his work, believing that by improving his stock and feed, his cattle will bring better prices. For this reason, he is turning to you for the support that would permit him to continue developing his business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle to raise

loans.name: Trần Thị

texts.en:
H. Trần Thị (14496777) is a 53-year-old female living in the town of Sóc Sơn. She is married and has three adult children.

H. owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over twenty years and earns approximately 3,500,000 VND a month.

In 1996, H. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.

H. is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. The loan will be her 14th from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Reina De Jesús

texts.es: Reina D. Jesús C. D. M. con 36 años D. edad resiD. en Atiquizaya ubicado en el departamento D. Ahuachapán. Reina vive con su suegro Don Oliveno D. 82 años D. edad, su hija Delmi y su esposo Fausto quien le ayuda en el negocio. Reina tiene una tienda en su casa donD. venD. variedad D. productos D. consumo y tiene 14 años D. tenerla. Delmi y su esposo dependen D. su negocio ya que es el único medio con el cual generan todo el ingreso económico para la familia es por eso que solicitan un crédito para seguir haciendo crecer su tienda, surtiéndola D. variedad D. productos con los cuales ningún cliente saldrá insatisfecho D. su negocio ya que todo lo encontraran allí.
texts.en:
36-year-old Reina D. Jesús C. D. M. lives in Atiquizaya in the Ahuachapán region. Reina lives with her 82-year-old father-in-law Don Oliveno, her daughter Delmi and her husband Fausto who helps her with the business.
Reina has run a shop out of her home for 14 years selling a variety of consumer products. Delmi and her husband depend on her business because it is the only way they generate the family income.
This is why they are requesting a loan to continue growing the store. They will stock a variety of products that will leave no client unsatisfied since they will find everything there.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Chhath

texts.en:
P. was born in 1981; she is a married woman and blessed with one lovely child who is minor and still not enrolled in school. P.'s husband's name is Thit, 20, and he works in construction.

P. has built a pigpen next to her house where she raises many pigs to earn a living. On the other hand, she also takes time to work on the farm. Soon the farming season is coming; she proposes to plant a rice crop, using a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed for growing.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed for growing

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is 56 years old and married with 6 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells yams and has been in the business since 1999.  She hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more yams to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for support.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell

loans.name: Obdulla

texts.en: Obdulla S. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 55 years old, is married, and has one adult child. Obdulla owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling umbrellas and shoe products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Obdulla joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Obdulla is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hannah Wangui

texts.en:
Hannah is a single mother aged 49 years old. She has two children Peter Muigai and Grace wanjiku aged 28 years and 20 years respecively. 

Hannah has been operating a retail shop in one of the biggest slums in Central Kenya. She also has put up and manages rental houses as a secondary business. It is through the income generated from these businesses,that she has been able to educate her children and take care of her family needs. Her son is currently in college.

Hannah was introduced to Kadet through an existing client and she has applied for her second loan which she plans to use to add stock e.g Rice,Potatoes and Tomatoes in her business. Hannah wishes to purchase a piece of land and build a home for her family using the extra profit from the  business. 

Her future dream is to open another business for her son to manage and be able to sustain himself.
She believes that she is a hardworking lady and that this is what has enabled her to achieve what she has. She also loves to keep her environment very clean. 


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add stock in her retail shop

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
This is Carmelita M., 23 years old, a young plastic wares dealer from Sta. Rita South, Tala, Caloocan City. She has one child.

Carmelita sells modular cabinets made of plastic, in various places, with her husband. She has been doing this for six years already. She is earning P 12,000 a month. Carmelita saves most of her profits for the future of her child.

She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007. Now on her 7th loan cycle, she has applied for a new loan in the amount of P8,000 as additional capital for her business. She dreams of having a larger plastic ware store where she can sell furniture as well.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna G. is from the village of Centro Napu, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. Myrna is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Myrna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Myrna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Mahfiratkhon

texts.ru: Махфиратхон Собирчонова проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 57 лет. Вдова, имеет 6 детей. Старший сын находится в России на заработках. Махфирахон более 30 лет занимается животноводством, она откармливает и продает скот. У нее имеются постоянные клиенты, мясники. Кредит просит для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Mahfiratkhon S. lives in the district of Rumi. She is 57-year-old widow with six children. Her oldest son is working in Russia. Mahfiratkhon has been a livestock breeder for over 30 years and has established relationships with clients. She raises and sells livestock. She is asking for a loan to purchase additional animals.

Translated from Russian by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Livestock purchase

loans.name: Santos

texts.es: Don santo e originario de la comunidad de chimente necesita de un credito para invertir su negocio en la compra de materiales de confeccion de mochila y aprovechando la vaciones de su hija y como el pedido que se tiene  para el inicio del ciclo es colar dos mil diez en poder satisfacer a su cliente pero lo que le hace falta es el capital de trabajo el confia en ASDIR que le va ayudar en el credito y el poder cumplir con dicho pedido y con ingreso que obtien mejor su nivel de vida y la de su familia, como podemos observar en las fotografia son personas muy sencillas pero trabajadores.
texts.en:
Don Santos is originally from the community of Chimente and needs a loan to purchase materials for making satchels. His daughter is home on vacation and available to help her father. Santos received his first order that is due in 2010, but he lacks the operating capital to satisfy this customer request. He is confident that Asociación ASDIR can assist him with a loan that will help him complete this order, and as a result, obtain a better standard of living for his family. As seen in the photograph, Santos and his daughter are simple people but hard workers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials for making satchels

loans.name: Hormiguitas Group

texts.es:
Rafael M. de 35 años tiene su movilidad con el cual trabaja, prestando servicio de transporte, pertenece a un sindicatoque tiene 15 rutas, específicamente trabaja en la ciudad de El Alto,  con el préstamo solicitado desea comprar las culatas para su movilidad ya que están en mal estado, él recuerda que antes era solamente chofer asalariado ahora con un esfuerzo se ha comprado su propia movilidad. Las demás integrantes  tienen sus propios negocios como el tejido de mantas, carpintería, venta de velas, confección de mochilas y taller de llantería. 
Todas necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería y materia prima.
texts.en:
Rafael M. is 35 years old. He has a small vehicle which he hires out, also, he is part of transportation union with 15 routes in the city of El Alto. With this loan he would like to replace the broken cylinder heads in his car. He remembers when he was only a driver and needed to rent a car. Now, with a lot of work, he has bought his own car. The other group members have their own businesses such as weaving, carpentry, selling candles, backpack making and a tire-repair shop. They need loans for buying merchandise and prime materials.

Translated from Spanish by Sierra Visher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Clementina

texts.es:
Clementina V. P. de 62 años de edad vive con su hija en casa de propia que le dejo como herencia su madre.
La Sra. Clementina es madre soltera, muy trabajadora y ha sido afectada por la inundación del año 1997 y por el terremoto del año 2007.
Ella se dedica a la venta de gaseosas y cervezas y también percibe un ingreso de pensionista por haber trabajado como empleada en una farmacia por mas de 30 años de servicios.
Su hija es profesional y goza de buenas referencias de parte de los vecinos.
Ella desea el financiamiento para poder invertir un poco mas en su negocio ya que estamos en pleno verano y tiene bastante salida las gaseosas y de esa manera obtener mejor ganancia que le permitirá cubrir mejor sus necesidades.
texts.en:
Clementina V. P. is 62 years old and lives with her daughter in her own home, which her mother left to her. Clementina is a hardworking single mother who was greatly affected by the 1997 flood and the 2007 earthquake.

She sells soft drinks and beer and also receives a pension after working in a pharmacy for more than 30 years. Her daughter has a professional job and enjoys a good reputation in the neighborhood.

Clementina is requesting a loan to invest in her business, as sales of cool drinks increase in the summertime. In this way, she will be able to increase her earnings and better cover her living expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
La Sra. Olga es cliente antigua, trabajo en grupo solidario CONFITAL, desD. el año 2001, actualmente ella trabaja con crédito individual.

La actividad que realiza es la crianza D. cerdos para luego venderlos en la ciudad ya que muchas personas consumen en los platos tipicos D. la ciudad como el fricase el chicharron y el plato tipico D. sucre la fritanga y el mondongo todos estos platos estan hechos a base D. la carne D. cerdo, ella tiene el esposo que trabaja en albañileria y sus hijos que son en su mayoria casados, excepto el menor que se encuentra en edad escolar, la Sra. es una persona muy buena y responsable, vive en casa propia en la zona D. Coqueni,ambos esposos son personas trabajadoras y cumplen con sus pagos en el crédito.						

Estan agradecidos con Emprender y con KIva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Olga is an old client and has worked in the solidarity group CONFITAL since 2001. Currently, she works with individual loans. Her job is to raise pigs in order to later sell them in the city since many people eat them in traditional dishes in the city like fricase, chicharron and fritanga and mondongo (the regional dish of Sucre). These dishes are all maD. with pork. Her husband works as a bricklayer and their children are mostly married, except for the youngest, who is still in school. Olga is a very good and responsible person and lives in her own home in the Coqueni region. Both spouses are hardworking people and make their loan payments on time. They are thankful to Emprender and to Kiva for the confidence shown in granting them the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy balanced food

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa, de 34 años, vive en su casa propia en compañía de su madre, sus hermanas y sus tres hijos: Paul (20), Angie (8) y Sayuri (4).
Desde hace 5 años se dedica a la venta de gas en su vivienda, los distribuidores le dejan los balones a concesión y ella los revende a un precio mayor. Le gusta mucho esta actividad porque es muy rentable, pues por la zona donde vive no tiene competencia y así obtiene muy buenas ganancias. Por otro lado, es un trabajo tranquilo y no requiere de mucho esfuerzo, ya que son sus clientes quienes vienen hasta su casa para llevarse los balones de gas; y en algunas oportunidades cuenta con la ayuda de sus hermanas o de sus hijos.
Paralelamente vende bebidas gaseosas y cervezas, teniendo mayor demanda durante los fines de semana. 
Para el futuro, Rosa planea acondicionar un espacio de su vivienda para instalar una pequeña tienda donde pueda vender sus bebidas y otros productos comestibles.

Este es el quinto préstamo que tiene con MFP y está segura que será muy responsable en el pago de sus cuotas, ya que no quiere quedar mal con la institución. El dinero que ahora solicita lo usará en la compra de balones de gas vacíos, bebidas gaseosas y varias cajas de cervezas.
texts.en:
Rosa is 34 and owns a home where she lives with her mother, her sisters, and her three children: Paul (20), Angie (8) and Sayuri (4). She has been selling tanks of gas from her home for 5 years. The wholesale distributors leave her the tanks, which she resells at a profit. She likes this work a lot because it is quite profitable, since in the area where she lives there is no competition and her earnings are good. In addition, it is a peaceful type of work that does not require her to exert herself too much, because her customers come to her house to get the tanks of gas, and at times she gets help from her sisters or her children. She also sells soft drinks and beer, which are in the most demand on the weekends. In the future, Rosa plans to remodel a part of her home in order to open a small store where she can sell her drinks and other foods. This is Rosa's fifth loan with MFP [Microfinanzas Prisma] and she is sure that she will be very responsible about repaying it, since she wants to keep a good relationship with this lending field partner. She will use the loan she is asking for now to buy tanks of gas, soft drinks, and various cases of beer.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of tanks of gas

loans.name: Maliemailatoelau

texts.en:
Maliemailatoelau L. is 28 and married with 5 children (ages 5 - 11).  She owns a business venture, selling ice-cakes (flavored ice in styrofoam cups).  Maliemailatoelau has many years of experience in this business.  Maliemailatoelau needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Maliemailatoelau joined SPBD.    This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Maliemailatoelau's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Maliemailatoelau L. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                         1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:            1.4 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:                1.6 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Angua

texts.en:
Angua S. is currently in the business of selling groundnut phase at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of groundnut to make phase to sell. Angua is 23 years old and is married with a husband that is a teacher. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy three plots for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of groundnut to make phase to sell.

loans.name: Clarisa

texts.es: Clarisa, tiene 56 años y junto a ella vive su esposo Gerardo de  45 años en su casa propia, ambos tiene dos hijos, adultos, siendo el mayor casado y la segunda viajó a la capital y actualmente trabaja y estudia, con el fin de tener un futuro mejor. El poseer tierras de cultivo, le ayudó para sacar a su familia adelante, es por ello que se dedica a la siembra de maíz, alverja, habas y verduras en general, pese a que su esposo cayo en el alcoholismo, tuvo que trabajar sola, pero ahora con la ayuda incondicional de su hermano mayor y sobrinos, quienes valoran su esfuerzo, se ocupan de cuidar la siembras, además pudo contratar operarios para apoyarla en la producción y cosecha. Es así que termina siendo negociante de su propia producción, llevándolos todos los miércoles de cada semana a la capital. Vendiendo diversidad de hortalizas frescas. Además de tener la responsabilidad total de su hogar, emprendió el negocio de venta de productos comestibles en una pequeña tienda que instaló en su casa. Por tal motivo espera ampliar su siembra y con ello cubrir la educación superior de su hija,  ya que su mayor anhelo es que sea una profesional. Este es su noveno crédito con MFP, por lo que espera cumplir su propósito, además le gusta trabajar con su grupo comunal, puesto que todos son personas responsables y con deseos de progresar. Con los dos mil quinientos nuevos soles que solicita, comprará una bolsa de semilla de alverja, dos sacos de abono y contratará más operarios para que le ayuden en la cosecha de papa, asimismo comprar productos para abastecer su pequeña tienda.
texts.en:
Clarisa, 56, lives with her husband, Gerardo, 45, in her own home. They have two adult children. Their oldest is married and their daughter moved to the capital to work and study in order to have a better future. Owning farm lands helped her support her family through by growingf corn, peas, broad beans and vegetables in general. Her husband fell into alcoholism and she had to work alone, although now she can count on unconditional help from her older brother and nephews, who value her work and help her out with caring for the crops. She has also been able to hire field workers to help with production and harvesting. Thus, she has become a merchant of her own production; she takes her products to the capital every Wednesday to sell a variety of fresh vegetables. Besides responsibility for her home, she started a small grocery selling business in a small store she set up in her home. She hopes to increase her crop production so that she can afford to pay for her daughter’s college education because her greatest wish is that her daughter becomes a professional. This is her 9th loan with MFP and she expects to meet her goal. Besides, she enjoys working in a communal group because all the members are responsible persons who wish to progress. She will use the 2500 new soles requested to buy a sack of pea seed, two sacks of manure and will hire more field hands to help with the potato harvest; she will also buy stock inventory items for her little store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pea seed and hire field workers.

loans.name: Ena Paola

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Familiar se reúne en la localidad Colorado en el  cantón Montecristi en la provincia de Manabí cerca al puerto Atunero Manta.

La señora Ena es socia desde hace 5 ciclos en la Fundación Espoir, ella es una joven madre de un niño de dos meses, se dedica a la venta ropa por catalogo y también compra ropa en Perú y Guayaquil según el pedido que tenga, contó  con el apoyo de su mamá en el tiempo que estaba en los meses de gestación  encargándose del negocio, ahora lo tiene que hacer ella aunque se le dificulta por el hecho que su bebe aún pequeño.

 Nuestra socia nos comenta  que ha sido de gran ayuda el trabajar con los créditos de la Fundación, su negocio ha ido creciendo muy bien y por ahora no ha tenido ningún tipo de problema con los pagos, con este nuevo crédito viajara  a Guayaquil para adquirir pantalones, Camisas, blusas, faldas, ropa interior para toda la familia  y  surtir su negocio  pues ya tiene varios pedidos pendientes por entregar.
texts.en:
The Familiar Communal Bank meets in the Colorado location. It is in the Montecristi region of the Manabí province, which is near the Atunero Manta port. Ena has been a member for five cycles with the Fundación Espoir. She is a young mother with a two month old child. She sells clothes by catalog. She also buys clothes in Perú and Guayaquil, according to the orders that she has. While she was pregnant, her mother helped her run the business. Now she has to do it even though it is difficult while her baby is still young. She tells us that working with the loans from the Fundación has been a big help. Her business has been growing very well. She has not had any problems with the payments. With this new loan she will travel to Guayaquil to get pants, shirts, blouses, skirts, and underwear for the whole family. She will stock her business as she has several pending orders to deliver.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pants, shirts, blouses, skirts, and underwear for the whole family

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San V., 50, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells bean sprouts for an income of about USD 6 per day. Her husband works as a militant in the province, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

V. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase seeds to sprout and jars to grow more sprouts for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy seeds to sprout and jars to grow more bean sprouts

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a hard-working farmer from Western Kenya in Kitale town. He is 31 years old and married, with 3 children aged 7 to 12 years old. All the children are currently attending school. He has been practising mixed farming for the last 8 years, producing maize, vegetables and tomatoes which he sells on the local market. He also earns some income from a tailoring business and transport services he offers with his motorbike. His biggest challenge in this farming business has been the high cost of fertilizers which has led to poor harvests.

John has successfully completed his second loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.40,000. He has requested this new loan from Juhudi for KES.40,000 to expand his poultry project and construct a cattle shed. He says that he has managed to acquire a dairy cow with the previous loan he was given and has been able to support his family with the income from that loan. He intends to have two more dairy cows that will increase his milk production so he will be able to supply milk to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries.

loans.use: expand his poultry project and construct a cattle shed

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em S., 51, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She is a housewife and her husband is a tuk-tuk driver who earns an income of USD 7 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a new tuk tuk. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

[S.'s husband appears in the photograph.]

loans.use: To buy a new tuk tuk.

loans.name: Meng

texts.en:
Mrs. K. is a young woman and the mother of a lovely young child who is not yet school-aged. K. has a family contributor in her husband who works in the construction field around the community.

In order to earn a daily income, K. plants different types of vegetable crops on her own land that she inherited from her grandparent. She is able to grow the crop twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. Because this annual farming business is a profitable one for family, K. requests a loan through Kiva to be used to hire a laborer to plow her farmland and then to buy seeds to grow and fertilizer.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to plow her farmland and to buy seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.en:
Vanessa V. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 31 years old. Vanessa is married and has 3 school-aged children.Vanessa owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Vanessa has been engaged in her business for over 10 years.

In 2007, Vanessa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Vanessa has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm materials. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Vanessa from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm materials

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey M., 54 years old, is a villager in Dei Chrab village in Takeo province. She is an age seller who is able to earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ba Em, is a farmer who owns a four-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family. 

While they both try to work hard, they still earn too little money. So to improve their family's living, Mrs. Srey M. is seeking a loan to buy a cow to raise. With the rest of the loan she will buy fertilizer to support her husband’s field and increase rice yield this year.

They have three children. One helps with the parents’ businesses and the other two attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy a cow to raise.

loans.name: Danny

texts.en:
Danny M. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 31 years old. Danny is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Danny owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Danny has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

Danny joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Danny has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Danny is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This will be the second loan taken out by Danny from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Palmier Plus Group

texts.en:
Jean Jacques N., aged 37, is the leader of the Community Bank named “Palmier Plus”, which is composed of 22 members united in solidarity to receive loans from MFI (micro-finance institution) HOPE RDC in order to develop their businesses. Jean Jacques started his business in 1998 selling fresh foods. He operates a drugstore in the western part of Kinshasa. 

Jean Jaques is a loyal client of MFI HOPE RDC who has already received five different loans and has repaid them properly. He intends to use the next loan to buy more medicine needed by his customers in his area to resell with the aim of increasing his profits. Each day, his business brings in a profit of US$ 10. 

His ambition is to expand his business by opening other drugstores in different places. Jean Jacques is married and has three children, who are aged between 3 and 12 years old. Two of them go to school.

loans.use: to purchase medicine needed by his customers

loans.name: Mbwana

texts.en:
Mbwana is a married woman with four children; three attend school while one is still too young for school. Her husband is a technician at the Kenya power and lighting company and he contributes to the family's basic needs. She has been operating her tailoring business for the last five years, selling in a shop and from home to her neighbors and passersby.

With the Kshs 70,000 loan, she wants to purchase clothing materials. Her other source of livelihood is her water stall business. She faces the major challenges of power blackouts leading to poor power supply. Mbwana decided to work with Yehu because of its easy procedures for joining. She owns a home with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is her license.

loans.use: To purchase clothing materials

loans.name: Elsy Edith

texts.es:
Elsy E. Solórzano vive en el barrio el bosque de Barranquilla con su cónyuge y sus 4 hijos en las edades de 11 a 20 años; ella está dedicada a la fabricación y venta de calzado para damas en diferentes estilos, lo que comenzó por la necesidad  de generar un mayor ingreso y familiar, pues hasta hace 7 años se dedicaban  a otra actividad poco rentable, así fue que pensó en buscar alternativas de mejorar sus ingresos familiares y se decidió por la zapatería;  como no tenia idea de cómo hacerlo, inició su aprendizaje    en el negocio de un amigo y desde ese momento no ha parado de trabajar en ella y con mucha perseverancia la ha sacado adelante hasta  lograr estabilizarla. Este es el primer crédito que recibe con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y con el planea invertir en materias primas e insumos para zapatería, como cuerina, y especialmente tela de jeans que está muy de moda y ha diseñado nuevas líneas que va a fabricar  y vender a su mayor cliente que es un almacén  de gran tamaño y  múltiples colmenas estacionarias en el sector comercial del centro de Barranquilla.

Su mayor desafío es ofrecer diversidad de diseños y estar siempre a la vanguardia de la moda, y poder sostenerse con calidad y poder cumplir su sueño de educar a sus hijos mediante su trabajo honrado y su negocio próspero.
texts.en:
Elsy E. Solórzano lives in the Woods of Barranquilla with her partner and their 4 children, ages 11 to 20. She makes and sells women’s shoes in different styles. She started the business because of her need to generate income for her family. 7 years ago she was involved in another type of work that wasn’t profitable. That’s when she began to look for alternatives to improve her family income and she decided on the shoe business. Since she had no idea how to make shoes, she began to learn in a friend’s business and since that time, she hasn’t stopped working in it. With a lot of perseverance she has been able to get ahead and stabilize her income. This is the first loan that she will receive with the Mario Santo Domino Foundation and she plans to use it to buy basic materials and supplies for making shoes, such as imitation leather, and especially jeans fabric (denim) that is very much in style. She has designed new lines that she will make and sell to her best customer, a large department store, and to many kiosks in the commercial area of the center of Barranquilla. The best part of her work is that she offers a variety in her designs and she is always in the vanguard of fashion. She is able to keep up the quality and fulfill her dream to educate her children with honorable work and a prosperous business.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic materials and supplies for shoemaking, such as imitation leather, and especially jeans fabric (denim)

loans.name: El

texts.en:
Mrs. El A. has established a small home in which she lives with other family members in the best territory located in Battambang Province. She is married, but doesn’t have a child yet.

El owns a piece of farmland that she and her husband inherited many years ago from their grandparents, growing rice and vegetable crops for the purpose of eating and selling. El A. now needs to borrow a loan to buy fertilizer to fatten her crops that are not growing well.

Mrs. El A.’s husband is pictured.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her crops

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine A. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  One of her children is currently in school.  Justine has a business making charcoal stoves, which she has had for four years.         

To help expand her business, Justine has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clay soil.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Justine hopes to generate greater profits and pay for school fees and food.  In the future, Justine hopes to own a salon or a tailoring shop.  Justine is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by changing her life. She now has a good meal in time and good shelter for her family from the loan she received.

loans.use: To buy more clay soil

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia is 50 years old, married and blessed with five children. She is a farmer who rears dairy cattle. Her farm is located in very fertile land which is conducive for her business. She supplies milk to hotels and individual clients. She also does horticultural farming. Her business has really grown since she joined Faulu Kenya. She has developed a saving habit. She sees herself owning a ranch and a pick-up for supplying milk in the future. She has requested 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy another dairy cow.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: George

texts.en: George Y. is 34 years old and operates a tuk tuk in Kilifi. A tuk tuk is a 3-wheeled vehicle used to transport people or things. George is married to a housewife, and they support two children. He has been in this business for the last five years and his income is good. As a member of KADET, he is requesting his second loan to add to his cash-on-hand to be able to purchase another tuk tuk. He will use the anticipated profit to build a permanent house for his family. He hopes in the future that he will be able to increase his cash flow.

loans.use: To purchase another tuk tuk

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva N. lives in the Kyebando neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, four of whom are in school. Eva has a business of selling fruits and vegetables. She has been in this business for years and she works 6 days out of every week. Eva sells her products in a market by means of retail.

Eva has requested for a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of tomatoes and onions. She gets additional income from rental rooms. The main business challenge(s) for Eva include transportation and perishability. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on wholesale only and also build more rental rooms. Eva lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of onions and tomatoes.

loans.name: Ishongororo  Twekundire Group-Ibanda

texts.en:
34 years old, T. Jane is a member of Ishongororo Twekundire Group-Ibanda. Jane and her fellow group members decided to take this photo in her shop.

This happily married mother of 3 has run her shop in Ishongororo Town for 9 years. Having started her shop with savings from selling goats, she continues to supplement her income through agriculture. Running the shop and farming both require hard work, dedication, resolve and courage. In that regard Jane has not failed. She earns 50,000 shillings weekly. Jane says with this loan, she is going to purchase more general merchandise for resale.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for resale

loans.name: Dukore Group

texts.en:
Sadiki is the group leader of five members, each with a different business. Sadiki is 43 years old and is married with one child who is one year old.

Sadiki works as a photographer. The hours of his business are from 7 am until 9 pm and this is his 4th successful year.

Sadiki is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more equipment for his photography business. Sadiki would like to earn more profits which will help him to save money for his children and to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more photography equipment.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson G. K. is 23 years old and single. To earn a living, he sells vehicle spare parts. He has engaged in the business for the past three years. He was previously employed in a restaurant before he started his own business.  

He hopes to have a fully established business in the future. He has requested a loan of 50,000 KES to buy starters, alternators and wipers.

loans.use: To buy starters, alternators and wipers

loans.name: Saraswati

texts.en: This is 50-year-old Saraswati T.. She is married and has two children, aged 30 and 26. In 2007, she established her cow-raising business. Working seven days a week and three hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy a young, milk-giving cow. In the future, Saraswati plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day. In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about $0.50. In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and can be captured in methane storage tanks. The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over. This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI (microfinance institution), Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business-training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates. Join our lending team.

loans.use: To buy a young, milk-giving cow

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida is 41 years-old and has one 24 year-old daughter. She has been selling mantas (colorful traditional blankets used to carry children or other goods) in Ayacucho for 7 years. She sells the blankets at local fairs or in towns in the surrounding area. She will be using her loan of 900 nuevos soles to buy wool to make blankets. 

Adelaida has been a member of FINCA Peru for 8 years, and has participated in the "Pueblo Libre" communal bank for the entire time. She even hosts some of its meetings in her home. She likes the communal bank concept at FINCA and the training that the organization offers to members. In the future, she would like to expand her house and sell her goods out of her home.

loans.use: To buy wool to make traditional blankets

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa M. is from the village of Linabu, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old. Luisa is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Luisa owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling seafood products  including fish such as sardines & mackerel in the local community. Luisa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish and as working capital. Luisa is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell such as salmon & sardines. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Luisa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell such as salmon & sardines

loans.name: The Tamarrneh United Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “Tamarrneh United” group. They are small-scale businesspeople in the eastern city of Kenema. This will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and gain better profit. 

Fatmata B. is the leader of this group. Fatmata was born in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. She is 32 years of age and married to a trader. They have two children. 

Fatmata sells slippers and has been doing this business for 10 years now. With the help of this loan, she will buy slippers in large quantity to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy slippers in large quantity to add to her business

loans.name: Ildefonso

texts.en:
Ildefonso O. is from the village of Canabuan Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 33 years old. Ildefonso is married and has 2 school-aged children. 

To make a living, Ildefonso plants and harvests rice for sale. Ildefonso has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 38000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Ildefonso joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He  is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This will be his  first loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchase fertilizer for his rice farm

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira is a 45 year old married woman, who lives with her husband in Chtoura. Since 2008, Samira has owned a small shop that sells home products, such as plastic bowls and tupperware. She has tried to improve her business more through adding gifts, accessories and cosmetics, but her business still needs more products to develop.

Samira has no children, and she had hoped to have children, so that's why she spends most of her time working in order not to feel lonely. Samira is a kind person, and she is loved by all of her customers who insist on passing by to check on her even though they don't want to buy anything. This is her third cycle with Al Majmoua, and each time she requested a loan to add new products to her small business. This time it is for the same reason, as she wants to support her cosmetics and accessories trade.

loans.use: to increase stock of cosmetics and accessories

loans.name: Lansana's Group

texts.en:
Pictured are teachers of the AL-Harrkan Primary School in Kabala, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This school was founded by the Sierra Leone Muslim Youth Cultural Organization in September of 2000 to promote education in the district. The school is staffed with 16 teachers and has an enrollment of 437 pupils. This will be the second loan that this group of teachers is accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. A previous Kiva lenders’ loan has tremendously helped in improving the standard of living of these borrowers. 


School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Lansana S., 50, is the leader of this group of teachers and has been a teacher for 16 years. He was born in Koinadugu district. He is married with 12 children – five in primary school, three in secondary school, two in college and two adults. Lansana will invest his loan in his business by buying local produce like rice, palm-oil, etc. at wholesale, to add to his business.

loans.use: to buy local produce like rice, palm-oil, etc., at wholesale

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es:
La señora Alejandrina C. tiene 46 años de edad y se dedica a prestar los servicios de moler maiz, tambien por las tardes se dedica a la venta de golosinas y tortillas.
el servicio de moler maiz lo hace muy temprano todos los dias, atiende a los pobladores de esa region, vive con sus 7 hijos, tiene casa propia,  con esfuerzo a sacado adelante a su familia y a arreglado su casa, Alejandrina es una mujer trabajadora y responsable que dia dia se esfuerza para salir adelante.
de las 9:30 a.m. en adelante vende jugos naturales, pastelitos, tacos en la gasolinera que esta cerca de su casa.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de repuestos para su molino.
Alejandrina desea que sus hijos tengan empleo para que asi colaboren con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Alejandrina is 46 years old and she grinds corn for a living. She grinds corn early every day for the residents of the region. Alejandrina lives with her 7 children in her own house. With much effort, she has advanced her family and finished her house. Alejandrina is a hard-working and responsible woman who day after day, works to get ahead.

From 9:00 am onward she sells natural fruit juices, pastries, and tacos in the gasoline station close to her house. Afternoons, she sells sweets and tortillas.

Alejandrina will use this loan to buy replacement parts for her corn grinding mill.

Alejandrina wants her children to gain employment so they too can contribute to household expenses.

loans.use: to buy replacement parts for her corn grinding mill.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María, de 25 años, es una mujer muy amable y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a sus 2 queridos hijos Alexis de 7 y Alejandra de 2 años, a quienes desea brindar una mejor calidad de vida. El negocio al que María se dedica es la venta de zapatos, los modelos que vende son muy novedosos y llamativos, lo cual ha hecho que tenga muchos clientes, quienes le hacen bastantes pedidos. Ella vende en la calle, recorriendo todos los días las calles del cono norte de la ciudad de Lima. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es ayudar a sus clientas a escoger el par de zapatos adecuado, lleva 2 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que caminar todo el día en busca de clientes. Con el tiempo, desea poner una tienda donde pueda atender con mayor tranquilidad a sus clientes. Este es el tercer crédito con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo y esta segura de poder hacerlo, al igual como hizo con sus primeros créditos, en su banco comunal siente que esta realizando una buena labor y que le tienen mucho respeto por la puntualidad que demuestra.
Con los seiscientos nuevos soles solicitados, comprará más zapatos, para tener una mayor variedad que ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Maria, who is 25 years old, is a very kind and hardworking woman. She lives in her own house together with her two beloved children, Alexis, who is 7, and Alejandra, who is 2, to whom she wants to offer a better quality of life. 

Maria's business is selling shoes. The styles that she sells are very trendy and showy, which has caused her to have many customers, who give her enough orders. She sells in the street, traveling through the streets in the north cone of the city of Lima every day. What she likes most about her work is helping her customers choose the right pair of shoes. She has had this business for two years, and she finds that the most difficult part is having to walk all day in search of customers. In time, she wants to set up a store where she can serve her customers more peacefully. 

This is her third loan with MFP. She knows that she has to make her payments on time, and she is sure she will be able to do it, just as she did with her first loans. In her communal bank she feels that she is doing good work and that they have much respect for the punctuality that she demonstrates. With the 600 PEN that she is applying for, she will buy more shoes, so that she has a greater variety to offer her customers.

loans.use: to buy more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Rayitos De Sol Group

texts.es: El grupo se llama “RAYITO DE SOL” y se encuentra ubicado en el estado de Morelos en México. Este grupo se encuentra integrado por 8 personas, una de las integrantes del grupo es la señora CLAUDIA, tiene 27 años de edad, es casada, tiene a sus 2 pequeños hijos de 10 y 5 años quienes estudian primaria y kínder, lleva 3 años viviendo en la comunidad donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura. La señora Claudia se dedica a la venta de calzado y cosméticos desde hace 5 años, ella solicita el prestamo para invertir en calzado y cosmeticos, ya que le hacen muchos pedidos y en ocasiones no tiene el suficiente dinero para comprar toda la mercancia que le piden, ella aprovecha las ofertas generando una mayor ganancia, permitiéndole el manejo de mejores precios a sus clientes ya que como ella tambien son madres trabajadoras y le gusta apoyarlas manejandoles pagos flexibles y comodos a sus posibilidades, con lo cual incrementa sus ventas y como resultado fortalece la economía familiar. Quiere ahorrar una parte de sus ganancias para la educación de sus hijos y darles una mejor calidad de vida. La señora que aparece en la parte de atras de blusa blanca es conocida de las integrantes del grupo que quizo salir en la foto, por esta razón aparecen 9.
texts.en: The group is called “Rayito de Sol” [Sunbeam] and it is located in the state of Morelos in Mexico. This group is made up of 8 people. One of the members of the group is Claudia, who is 27 years old, married, and has 2 small children who are 10 and 5 years old and who are studying in primary school and kindergarten. She has been living in this community for 3 years, where most of the inhabitants work in agriculture. Claudia has been selling shoes and cosmetics for 5 years. She is requesting the loan to invest in shoes and cosmetics because people place many orders with her, and sometimes she doesn’t have the money to buy the merchandise they request. She takes advantage of sales to generate greater profit. This allows her to give better prices to her clients who, like her, are hard-working mothers and she likes to help them out by extending them flexible and comfortable payments within their means. This increases her sales, and as a result, strengthens the economic situation of her family. She wants to save a portion of her earnings for her children’s education and give them a better quality of life. The lady who is in the back [of the photo] in a white blouse is a friend of the members of the group and she wanted to be in the photo, so that is why there are 9 people in it.

loans.use: to buy shoes and cosmetics for her business.

loans.name: Sainte Therese De L Enfant Jesus Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 11 novembre 2009. Le groupe est  composé de onze femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.
Madame Sabine qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main et le responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 45 ans. Elle est mariée et mère d'un enfant. Elle a aussi en sa charge deux autres enfants confié par ses parents.
Elle s’active dans la vente des huitres. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, qu'elle pratique depuis plusieurs années.
Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.
Les profits lui permettront de participer à la prise en charge des frais de scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
The solidarity group was founded on November 11, 2009. The group has 11 woman members who live in the same neighborhood. They work together in small businesses.

Mrs. Sabine, on the right with her hand raised, is the leader of the group. She is 45 years old. She is married and has one child. She also takes care of two other children entrusted by her parents.

She is in the business of selling oysters. She has a lot of experience as she's been in business for several years.
This loan will allow her to strengthen her capital and further grow her business.

The profits will allow her to contribute in paying the school expenses of her children.

loans.use: to purchase oysters

loans.name: Raquel De La Concepcion

texts.es: Raquel tiene 42 años, por lo que su actividad económica es la venta de granos básicos. Hace más de 3 años que se dedica a este negocio. Ella ofrece una variedad de granos básicos. Es una persona muy alegre y trabajadora por lo que vive muy feliz con su negocio a pesar de ganar mucho con este negocio le proporciona lo necesario para mantenerse a ella y la familia. Ella solicita urgentemente para comprar frijoles, azúcar, aceite, arroz, concentrado maíz entre otros. Su deseo es mantener siempre su record crediticio porque sin él no podría avanzar con su negocio.
texts.en:
Raquel is 42 years old and earns her livelihood by selling dry goods. She has been in business for more than three years and offers a variety of dry goods. Raquel is a cheerful and hardworking person who is very happy with her business. Even though she spends a great deal of time managing her business, it provides her what she needs to support herself and her family.

Raquel is submitting an urgent request so that she can buy beans, sugar, oil, rice, concentrated corn, and other products. Her wish is to constantly maintain her credit record, because without it she is not able to advance her business.

loans.use: to purchase beans, sugar, oil, rice, concentrated corn, and other products.

loans.name: Khut

texts.en: Mrs. Khut lives in a village in the province of Kompong Cham. She sells a few wares in front of her home. She sells items like soft drink, sweets for kids and some cooking supplies. She earns an average income of $2.50 each day to cover her family’s needs. She is a single mother who has a school-aged child. Recently, Mrs. Khut’s inventory has been exhausted; she wants to resupply and is requesting a loan to build up her inventory so she can continue selling.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Mirna Guadalupe

texts.es: Mirna Guadalupe D. treinta y nueve años D. edad vive con su compañero D. vida y sus hijos. Ella posee una venta D. antojitos como enchiladas, empanadas, tamales, pastelitos, entre otros su venta tiene mucha demanda pues sus antojitos tienen un sabor exquisito y los venD. a un precio accesible, además, Mirna le da a sus clientes el mejor servicio siempre está a la disposición D. lo que necesiten; es una mujer emprendedora con muchas ganas D. salir adelante por eso le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar materia prima por mayor como maíz, aceite, huevos, verduras, y gas propano.  Mirna Guadalupe tiene la esperanza D. que con su esfuerzo logrará darle a su familia una mejor calidad D. vida.
texts.en: Mirna Guadalupe is 39 years old living with her life companion and their children.  She sells fast food snacks like enchiladas, turnovers, tamales, cakes, among others.  Her snacks are delicious and she sells them for affordable prices so they are in very high demand.  Mirna gives her customers the best possible service always and is always willing to proviD. what they wish.  She is an enterprising woman with a strong will to get ahead.  This is why she’s asking INTEGRAL for a loan to buy raw materials like corn, oil, eggs, vegetables and propane gas.  Mirna Guadalupe hopes that her efforts will lead to a better quality of life for her family.

loans.use: to buy corn, oil, eggs, vegetables and propane gas.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married and God has blessed her marriage with two lovely children, one of whom is below the age of fifteen. She lives with her family in a one-bedroom house in Rendez-vous, a quarter in Bamenda, of the Northwest region of Cameroon.

The major challenge she has faced in life has been poverty, including insufficient money to treat herself when she was sick and difficulty in paying her house rent.
